TITLE: Why is reading the documentation so important?
TEXT:
Why is reading the documentation so important?

Human brains are lazy engines. They almost always choose the â€œshortestâ€ way to go from point A to point B. 

When writing code it goes like this: 
âœ…write code
ğŸ˜¢encounter error
ğŸ˜¬modify code
ğŸ˜¡encounter error
ğŸ˜go to StackOverflow
ğŸ¥³copy code
ğŸ˜run code
ğŸ¥¶repeat.

â€¦this is no where near from effiency! 

When you avoid reading the documentation, youâ€™re missing out on understanding the bigger picture and the deeper mechanical processes behind your code.

This leads to writing less efficient code.

I know because Iâ€™ve being doing it recently with Plotly Dash library.

ğŸ˜©Everything was right here, in the docs, but my brain was too lazy to read the details and understand the situation.

Do you relate?

Btw we worked with Shloka Gupta on a nice rework of https://docs.naas.ai so if you want to get started, I suggest you start there ğŸğŸ˜‰

PS: the good thing is all the templates are available in naas docs, just click on â€œopen in naasâ€ button and get things done âœ”ï¸ 

Cheers!

TITLE: â° Save your time and schedule your notebook like a script!
TEXT:
â° Save your time and schedule your notebook like a script!


To schedule your Jupyter Notebook using Papermill in naas.ai, you just need to add this simple formulağŸ‘‡.

import naas
naas.scheduler.add(cron="0 * * * *") â† this cron argument is the standard syntax worldwide. It means every hour in that case.

Press play â–¶ï¸ and your notebook will be sent to the Naas "âš¡ï¸Production folder".

Every time your notebook is executed, a record will be stored in this folder so you can access it if it fails.

Try now following this video: https://lnkd.in/erXctqWD

Thanks, Caleb Keller for the inspiration for my post!

TITLE: â­ï¸ Notebooks are the best medium ever created to work with data.
TEXT:
â­ï¸ Notebooks are the best medium ever created to work with data. 
But they also have their downsides....

...if you don't use them properly. 

My take is that it's about how we use notebooks, the notebooks are not responsible for bad coding habits. 

They are very permissive by nature, so if you are not rigorous, they can be very dirty, and I hate it. ğŸ˜¡

At naas.ai we are going way beyond notebooks, inspired by the work done at Netflix. 

We believe in clean, well formatted, versioned Notebooks that can be used as building blocks to create a generation of data products where code, documentation and execution live at the same place.

That's why we are building the biggest catalog of notebooks templates ever with our community (Check our GitHub repo in the comment)

â†’ If you are interested in the subject, here is a 20min conversation I had with Mehdi Ouazza a couple of weeks ago. 

Like a lot of people in data, he has a love and hate relationship with notebooks, but you will see that we agree on many points. 

Let's fight dirty Notebooks, for good ğŸ˜œ

TITLE: ğŸŒ±âš¡ï¸ What I see in the data industry is the rise of a "Lean Data Stack" movement.
TEXT:
ğŸŒ±âš¡ï¸ What I see in the data industry is the rise of a "Lean Data Stack" movement.

Let me explainğŸ‘‡

In the current market dynamics ğŸ“‰, we need to find a way of eliminating waste from data operations to create sustainable data products.

Where the only thing that matters is the value you deliver. Not the team, not the tool, nothing but the value you deliver.
And this way is called Lean. Like on lean manufacturing.

It is not necessary to collect all data all the time for every single use case. We want our tools to help us explore the true value of data from features, drivers, predictive scores, and more.

The industry is broken and needs fixing. "Big data" has created a world full of wasteful practices, we need "Smart data".

ğŸ™ We need a data ecosystem that is conscious of this situation and is ready to change. We need to create a culture where open source prevails and techniques are shared with the world openly.

ğŸš€ It's not rocket science. It's just common sense:

1ï¸âƒ£ Always start with customer understanding (find a problem you're solving)
2ï¸âƒ£ Identify data sources in potential solutions (eg Google Analytics, CRM data, etc)
3ï¸âƒ£ Create a clear product backlog with actionable tasks (eg clean your data, reduce maintenance costs).
4ï¸âƒ£ Create an iterative business model (start testing ideas then build on success)
5ï¸âƒ£ Learn quickly from what you've built (conduct customer interviews and adjust based on feedback as well as customer behavior)

The core components of the lean data stack are serverless compute, managed services and open source. 

There are no silos in lean data; security and analytics can be integrated to make it an end-to-end stack.

â†’ There are so many great minds out there working on the topic. I really hope we can get this fixed together, and that the naas.ai open source community and I can be a part of it.

I think we have a pretty good idea of how to make this happen from the feedback of our first customers. cc Joshua Alvernia

This day 60 of my #66daysofdata, thanks a lot for the support ğŸ’š. Happy to share thoughts in the comment.

TITLE: â˜„ï¸ The data industry is entering a new cycle, did you notice?Â
TEXT:
â˜„ï¸ The data industry is entering a new cycle, did you notice?Â 

It's less about tech, and more about business outcomes, and it's a good thing. It means the market is maturing.

A lot of articles and posts are now talking about moving from building data platforms to building data products.Â 

But it's still hard to find good examples of what data products can be, and how they are integrated in the strategy of a company.

If you are interested in this topic, read our first customer story.

ğŸ‘‡ In this article you will learn aboutÂ Clue's vision to build world-class suite of data products to provide answers to business needs faster, and better withÂ naas.ai

I'm so glad to partner with such an incredible team!

A special thanks toÂ Joshua Alvernia,Â Joanna Taccone,Â Vidula Ashok (she/her)and all the people behind the scenes at Clue.

Let's move the industry forward with data products built on top of open source to ensure ownership and sustainability ğŸ’š

TITLE: It's time to stop burning cash ğŸ”¥ğŸ’°. Companies need to calm down on data platforms and start building data products instead.
TEXT:
It's time to stop burning cash ğŸ”¥ğŸ’°. Companies need to calm down on data platforms and start building data products instead. 

The job to be done is simple: tap into the leader's brain ğŸ§  and translate their vision into products.

ğŸ‘‡

These products need to be a reflection of the way they want to operate the business and gain a competitive advantage.

These products need to be designed not only to solve internal business problems but also to create new business opportunities. 

These products should have their own P&L, revenue should be obvious, and costs should be transparent.

These products are to be treated as Assets on the balance sheet and be deprecated over time. 

These products cannot be built on top of closed-sourced technologies, they need to rely on open source to ensure full ownership.

These products should be self-sufficient, autonomous, and could be deployed in any context. 


â†’ I hear a lot of voices rising up in that direction, and I'm excited. ğŸ¥³

Because everything stated above is what we have in mind since day 1 with naas.ai, and as the market is now evolving toward this, we are getting ready to go all-in. 

Tomorrow, I will share with you our very first customer story article. I hope it will encourage more companies to bet on our core team, our community, and the power of open source ğŸ’š

 Stay tuned.

TITLE: âœŒï¸ğŸ“Š How to create amazing dashboards using Plotly Dash?
TEXT:
âœŒï¸ğŸ“Š How to create amazing dashboards using Plotly Dash?

Today, we learned more about it thanks to Elias Dabbas, our naas.ai community expert on Dash and Marketing data. 

This is a summary of what we talked about: 

â†’ What makes a dashboard UI: simple navigation and charts, dynamic filtering, reference to a perimeter and a timeframe (a number alone does not mean anything)

â†’ The importance of domain knowledge to make the right design choices or the need for a "wireframe" before starting coding anything

â†’ The difference between dashboards and apps: dashboards are mainly outputs, they don't send data or instructions to a back-end, apps do.

â†’ Preprocessing vs post-processing data: many people use dashboarding tools as query engines (post-processing) when they should instead optimize in advance (pre-process) for speed and UX

â†’ How Dash leverages Bootstrap to create clean layouts very easily, and why using such framework is important to make your dashboards responsive

â†’ What are the callbacks functions and how they are used to populate charts into the dashboard layouts, but also open the door to very powerful dynamic filtering 

It was such an insightful session, we learned a lot.

Tomorrow, we will start applying this in the context of our summer-dashboarding project on GitHub

If you want to follow what we are doing or even contribute, just ping me in the comment and I'll reach out to you. 

Cheers ğŸ¤™

Btw, this was day 57/ #66daysofdata and I'm not sure I'm going to stop after 66 days ğŸ˜…âœŒï¸

Today.

Nothing more to say, except that I really wish we can reverse this trend ğŸ‘‡

Do you think it can work for you?

TITLE: ğŸª£ Why we useÂ Amazon Web Services (AWS)Â S3 as our company data lake?
TEXT:
ğŸª£ Why we useÂ Amazon Web Services (AWS)Â S3 as our company data lake?

Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3) is an object storage service that offers scalability, data availability, security, performance and is very cost effective.

It falls into the "Data Lake" category of data tools.
= push all your unstructured data into a bucket, and leverage the power of the cloud to make sense of it.

AmazonÂ uses it to run its global e-commerce network,
NetflixÂ uses it as the fabric of their big data ecosystem,
but it can also serve smaller companies.

AtÂ naas.ai, we use it to store:
â¡ï¸ Events data from our product
â¡ï¸ Contents data extracted from social media platforms
â¡ï¸ Customers data from multiples sources

It enables us to:
âœ… Create our product KPIs
âœ… Follow our social media performance through multiple accounts
âœ… Enrich our CRM automatically with quality insights

We have created super cool notebook templates to work with it, so feel free to use out (link of the repo in the comment) â­ï¸

ğŸ‘‰ If you need any help or feedback on how to get the most of working with S3, I'm more than happy to share our experience! ğŸ’š

Cheers, and have a nice Sunday!

TITLE: People care too much about the code, not enough about the outcomes.
TEXT:
People care too much about the code, not enough about the outcomes.

I'm saying because,
I've been interviewing 20 people this week for our "open source dashboarding summer internship", all of them are young talented minds. 

The game was simple, a 15min interview â†’ an answer in 1 week.
- 5 min â†’ pitching their story 
- 5 min â†’ pitching Naas story + Q&A
- 5 min â†’ pitching a dashboard they have created ğŸ“Š

BUT you know what?

ğŸ”´ 80% of them started pitching me the code, when it came to presenting their dashboard ğŸ˜…

One of my favorite sentence to back this up is : "Start with the user experience, then work backward to technology" from Mr Jobs. 
ğŸ

This is just a gentle reminder. 

=> Pitch the results, not the mean.

Cheers.

TITLE: Is inflation that bad?
TEXT:
Is inflation that bad? 

Well...if we look at the Customer Price Index vs a 2% inflation rate ğŸ‘‡

Fed was doing a good job keeping inflation steady, but it seems like: 
- pandemic stimulus in 2020
- supply chain issues in 2021
- war in Ukraine in 2022
....and most likely other factors, are pushing the inflation way above the "normal". 2% rate.

The Consumer Price Index (CPI) isÂ a measure of the average change over time in the prices paid by urban consumers for a market basket of consumer goods and services. 
Indexes are available for the U.S. and various geographic areas. 

Today, I explored created a awesome-notebooks template on the topic. 
I used an article suggested by Carlo Occhiena to fit it into the naas.ai framework. 

If you want to play with the notebook, check the link in the comment.

TITLE: Large language models (LLMs) have made a significant impact on AI research.
TEXT:
Large language models (LLMs) have made a significant impact on AI research. 

These powerful, general models can take on a wide variety of new language tasks from a userâ€™s instructions. 

However, academia, nonprofits and smaller companies' research labs find it difficult to create, study, or even use LLMs as only a few industrial labs with the necessary resources and exclusive rights can fully access them. 

Today, we release BLOOM, the first multilingual LLM trained in complete transparency, to change this status quo â€” the result of the largest collaboration of AI researchers ever involved in a single research project.

â€” ğŸŒ¸Introducing The Worldâ€™s Largest Open Multilingual Language Model: BLOOMğŸŒ¸ by Hugging face 

Guys, this company is really going to change the face of AI.

This is all i need to say today. 
Read the article, if you want to learn more: 

https://lnkd.in/e7hJMzUA

TITLE: It's official, temperatures could again exceed 40Â°C next week in France. The 2nd heatwave in a month.
TEXT:
It's official, temperatures could again exceed 40Â°C next week in France. The 2nd heatwave in a month.

Global warming isn't the future. It's happening right now, and already has consequences.

Consequences for humans, where the people who will suffer will again be the same: the oldest, the most precarious, etc.

Consequences for our agriculture. Depending on the amplitude and duration, there are risks of agricultural losses (more info to come this week on that).

Consequences for animals. Livestock, which do not always have the best conditions to withstand very hot weather. Our domestic animals too.

Politicians who talk about punitive ecology are irresponsible.
Politicians who do not engage in structural transformations in 2022 to drastically lower our emissions and adapt ourselves are irresponsible.

I will communicate at each heatwave, each flood, each drought and will remind each time that without changing the economic system, we will suffer more and more climatic hazards, and personally, the 50Â°C in my city, it does not make me dream at all.

-- Bon Pote 

Go follow Bon Pote - English. Amazing content raising consciousness on climate-care urgency.

It's too late to be a pessimist.  
Everyone can make a contribution. 

If you want to contribute to the open source / data science domain on climate data, please comment ğŸ‘‡ . 

â†’ I believe we need to programmatically create content that educates and raises consciousness on our planet's health metrics and distribute it massively across popular social platforms.
naas.ai can help us do that. 

Does anyone want to work on this?

TITLE: ğŸ”¥ Heat maps are really under-rated.
TEXT:
ğŸ”¥ Heat maps are really under-rated.

This graph is almost never seen in business data visualization.

Heat maps are graphical representations of data that utilize color-coded systems.

The primary purpose isÂ to better visualize the volume of locations/events within a dataset and assist in directing viewers towards areas that matter most.

They are one of the most useful and powerfulÂ data-analysis toolsÂ available in business intelligence; in my opinion.

GitHubÂ use this to show how intense your activity is on the platform.

So we made the same on LinkedIn.

In the image below, you can quickly see that Oct 2021 and June 2022 are the most active month and that Wednesday is when I'm the post consistent at posting.

Do you like this viz?
Are you using heatmaps in your business?

TITLE: What are the differences between naas.ai and Google Colab?
TEXT:
What are the differences between naas.ai and Google Colab?   

The main difference between naas.ai and Google Colab is that naas.ai is a platform that allows users to train and deploy machine learning models, while Google Colab is a free cloud service that offers Jupyter Notebooks. 

Naas.ai also offers a number of features that are not available on Google Colab, such as model sharing and collaboration, model management, and model deployment.

ğŸ‘†
this is what Open AI answered me today.

I used the text generation API and extended it to 4k words 
This is the first shot. 

Not bad, but Naas is not only for machine learning models. 
â†’ we deploy anything that speedup adoption of future-proof data solutions around the world.

...And today day 33 of #66daysofdata, I had fun customizing Naas like a Google colab. 

Would you spot the differences?
Wrong answers only.

TITLE: Are you looking for a way to make your quarterly P&L review easier to understand?
TEXT:
Are you looking for a way to make your quarterly P&L review easier to understand?

Try the waterfall chart.

A waterfall chartÂ shows a running total as values are added or subtracted. 

It's useful for understanding how an initial value is affected by a series of positive and negative values. 

The columns are color coded so you can quickly tell positive from negative numbers.

TITLE: âš¡ï¸ğŸ“Š Serve your business faster with Jupyter Notebook and naas.ai framework!
TEXT:
âš¡ï¸ğŸ“Š Serve your business faster with Jupyter Notebook and naas.ai framework!

20 days ago, we gave ourselves a month to create a data product that automates the aggregation and analysis of data from various social platforms and visualizes the results in a Notion dashboard.

The objective was to: 
- do it because we needed to follow our own content 
- build it in public to show how Naas can be used to create data products

Here are the steps we followed:
 
1. ğŸ“º Define where the data will be consumed
Notion came out naturally, it's the go-to tool for a lot of businesses today.

2. ğŸ“Š Design the reports and charts
Thanks to our data/BI consulting experience and the templates in naas.ai awesome-notebooks repository, we got started super fast!
 
3. âš¡ï¸ Create an V0 of an engine
The engine is how different templates can work together. We modularised templates and started assembling them, isolating the config and pipeline logic in specific notebooks.

4. â­ï¸ Publish the project on GitHub
Once we got a first social media tool covered (LinkedIn) we started packaging the data product on GitHub. 
We are now duplicating the model on the other social platforms (Youtube, Twitterâ€¦)

AND, now it's the time to show YOU what we have. 

ğŸ—“ Next week during our community call, we are going to share in details how this product is working, so you can get inspired and maybe build one as well!

We will focus on the business side and the tech side of things. Because both are important to make an impact with your data product.

So, to all the notebooks lovers ğŸ’š and notebooks haters ğŸ’šğŸ’š, feel free to join us for the first event ever on how build in public data product using notebooks ğŸ˜‡

I really hope to see you there, check out the link in the comment to register.

TITLE: Do you want to follow the trend of keywords on Google Search over time?
TEXT:
Do you want to follow the trend of keywords on Google Search over time? 

Today I learned how to use pytrends to do that. 

It was quite simple to implement.

â†’ import pytrends 
â†’ setup trend request: language, timezone (example: US CST isÂ '360')
â†’ build payload with keywords list, it can be a simple word or a list (cf example)
â†’ choose the API method you want and plot the results! 

The API methods you have access to : 
- Interest Over Time
- Historical Hourly Interest
- Interest by Region
- Related Topics
- Related Queries
- Trending Searches
- Top Charts
- Suggestions

Check out the doc in the comment to lean more! 

Hope you find this useful.

TITLE: If you are interested in data and business, you need to read this article about data products.
TEXT:
If you are interested in data and business, you need to read this article about data products. 

Below is the summary, but I really suggest you read it all ğŸ‘‡

-------------------
Most companies struggle to capture the enormous potential of their data. 

Typically, they launch massive programs that try to meet the needs of every data end-user or have individual application-development teams set up customized data pipelines that canâ€™t easily be repurposed. 

Firms instead need to figure out how to craft data strategies that deliver value in the near term and at the same time lay the foundations for future data use.

Successful companies do this by treating data like a commercial product. 

When a business develops a product, it tries to maximize sales by addressing the needs of as many kinds of customers as possible with itâ€”often by creating a standard offering that can be tailored for different users. 

A data product works similarly. It delivers a high-quality, easy-to-use set of data that people across an organization can apply to various business challenges. It might, say, provide 360-degree views of customers, of employees, or of a channel.

Because they have many applications, data products can generate impressive returns. The customer data product at one large bank, for instance, has nearly 60 use cases, and those applications generate $60 million in incremental revenue and eliminate $40 million in losses annually."

-------------------
Read the full article on Harvard Business Review:
https://lnkd.in/ed3_MKUz

This was day 25/ #66daysofdata challenge.
Learning more about data every day!

TITLE: Did you know that you can create very clean input forms with ipywidgets?
TEXT:
Did you know that you can create very clean input forms with ipywidgets? 

Jupyter Widgets areÂ interactive browser controlsÂ for Jupyter notebooks. 

You can use them for: 
- Basic form controls like sliders, checkboxes, text inputs
- Container controls like tabs, accordions, horizontal and vertical layout boxes, grid layouts
- Advanced controls like maps, 2d and 3d visualizations, datagrids, and more

Notebooks really come alive when interactive widgets are used. 

Users can visualize and manipulate their data in intuitive and easy ways. 

Anyone can easily see how changing inputs to a model impact the results. 

One of the cool things is that others can play with it without seeing the code. 

â†’ Exploring, learning, and sharing becomes a fun immersive experience. 

Check out the example attached in GIF, would you use this for your projects?

TITLE: What's so hard about applied AI?
TEXT:
What's so hard about applied AI? 

It is probably not what you think it is.

First, let's make it clear that there are 3 types of people working with machine learning/AI: 

1ï¸âƒ£ "The researchers": inventing new kinds of algorithms. 
2ï¸âƒ£ "The creators": applying machine learning algorithms to data pipelines, like chefs taking ingredients to make a nice dish.

"The creators" job consists mostly in installing a whole bunch of machine learning packages and then tuning the best algorithms to fit a specific business problem.

"The creators" are not going to magically figure out which algorithm is the right solution... 
They have to try lots of things. 
If the problem is easy and well defined, they can solve it quickly. 
If it isn't, they can weeks or months before any progress is made.

There is a lot of failing. 
There's a lot of iteration until they succeed.

And you know what? 
Often, they don't...
and it's often not because of their technical skills IMHO.  

It's because of their lack of connection with the 3rd type of people: 
3ï¸âƒ£ "The consumers": the only judge and jury, only they can tell if the work done is useful or not, even if they don't understand the technicalities. 

Not every problem is going to be solvable by datasets, applied AI is about people, not algorithms.

That's why it's so hard. 

TLDR
Dealing with people is hard. AI is no exception.


That's it for today. Day 22 of my #66daysofdata. 
Hope you find this content useful ğŸ˜‡

This post is inspired by a video from Cassie Kozyrkov and the review of a contribution made today on naas.ai by Abhinav Lakhani during our community call. ğŸ¤™

TITLE: âœŒï¸Zen and the Art of Data Science
TEXT:
âœŒï¸Zen and the Art of Data Science 

You may be new or experienced data scientists, you cannot avoid to face frustration and loss of momentum in your projects. 

Today I read an article that propose the following steps to deal with hang-ups and setbacks.

I can totally relate. Do you?

ğŸ‘‡

ğŸ“Take notes. 
When making plans and talking to stakeholders, take some time to jot down your thoughts. Ensure that expectations are clearly aligned. Writing things out helps to formalize and structure the process.

ğŸList requirements and objectives. 
Get a grasp on what conditions need to be met and what constitutes a successful project. Be as specific as possible. Using SMART criteria is often helpful.

ğŸ™‹â€â™‚ï¸Define clear research questions. 
What insights should you obtain from the data? What capabilities should your new algorithm have? If you want to find the right answers, make sure you ask the right questions.

ğŸŒ±Plan in advance. 
Break down the project into a logical sequence of comprehensive steps. What activities are needed for each step, how long should they take? What data and tools are needed to successfully complete the project? A clear pathway drastically increases chances of success.

ğŸ§˜â€â™€ï¸Frequently reflect. 
The previous steps are not set in stone once you set off. Projects are dynamic, objectives and questions may change, newly arising obstacles should be resolved. Take the time to reflect during your data science project, and donâ€™t be afraid to alter course


This is it for today. 
Reading, doing, learning everyday ğŸ¤™

TEXT:
AI image generation models are impressive, but they may also reinforce or exacerbate societal biases.

Today, day 17 of #66dayofdata, 
I played with DALLÂ·E mini model provided by Hugging Face ğŸ¤— 

You can enter any words as input, the model will generate 9 images as an output. 

I wanted to understand what kind of things you can get. I was quite suprised when I looked at all the results published by the community. 

It does not feel right to me when it involves faces IMHO (example below, only white faces)

Nonetheless, I think this tool can be the beginning of a whole new era of creativity for content creators and artists ğŸŒ±ğŸ–¼

TITLE: Why do you need a design system for your graphs? and how we built one for social media aggregator project today.ğŸ‘‡
TEXT:
Why do you need a design system for your graphs? and how we built one for social media aggregator project today.ğŸ‘‡

A design system isÂ a complete set of standards intended to manage design at scale using reusable components and patterns.

It takes the pressure off of design resources to focus on larger, more complex problems (like data collection, cleaning, modelling...you see the idea?)

So here is what we looked at for our social media graphs:  

ğŸ¨ Branding
A logo of the tool (i.e. LinkedIn), and took the primary color (blue) minus 25% of intensity to make it soft to the eyes.

ğŸ’¬ Title
A clear title expressing the metric and the timeframe.

âˆ‘ Total 
A total value of the metric we look at.

âœ… This month 
A variation of the last values we look at in value and in %

â†’ As the elements above are on the top right, your eyes will likely go here first. In 3 seconds you have the key ideas. 

ğŸ“Š Graph 
A bar graph to see how the data is distributed.

ğŸ· Data labels
The number of each bar on top assess the performance of previous period vs current one and the month in 3 letters format + Year.

Nothing more.
We are going to duplicate this for Youtube, Twitter, Instagram,...

Do you like this? Anything you think we should add?

Hope you find this post useful.

TITLE: ğŸ“ŠğŸ“‰ How to choose between a bar graphs, and line graphs?
TEXT:
ğŸ“ŠğŸ“‰ How to choose between a bar graphs, and line graphs? 

When to mix both? 

Bar graphs show data with blocks of different lengths, whereas line graphs show a series of points connected by straight lines. 
This leads to a very different appearance, that's a given.

The biggest difference is that bar graphs are more versatile while line graphs are better for showing trends over time or another measure with a logical progression of values (such as distance from a given point). 

Bar graphs can also show frequency distributions (how often you observe different outcomes), or ranking.

In other words: 
ğŸ“‰ Use Line graphs to track changes over short and long periods of time, and compare changes for more than one group.
ğŸ“Š Use Bar graphs to compare things between different groups or to track changes over time, best when the changes are larger.

What about bar line? 
Use them if you need to compare data on with 3 parameters. Line being the discrete data, bar tend to show the most important dataset you want to show.

Does that makes sense to you? Please share your thoughts below.

Today, we took time with Florent to think about the graphs we need to in the social media data aggregator we are building in public. That's a very important part of the process
â†’ Do not underestimate it, do not rush into the data, think about the end-user experience! ğŸ”´

TITLE: If you are planning to be relevant in business over the long term, you need to consider putting out 64+ content a day.
TEXT:
If you are planning to be relevant in business over the long term, you need to consider putting out 64+ content a day. 
--Â Gary Vaynerchuk.

ğŸ‘† If you don't know this guy, you need to check him out, he is probably the most influential serial entrepreneur out there. 
The symbol of hustle, execution and digital advertising. 

So when he say 64+ content, it may sounds a little bit too much for us, normal human beings. 
But the idea does actually make sense.

Your work needs to be visible. 
If no body know what you are doing, your work does not exists. 

ğŸ”´ There is one problem though, if you want to execute this strategy You want to measure it. 

â†’ And, there is no tool that (to my knowledge) does that across the 5-10 platforms that matters.

So as we have build very cool data science templates on LinkedIn, Twitter, YouTube... we started brainstorming with the team about a "data product" that could do that.

It could be: 
- an app 
- a dashboard 
- a report
- an email digest 
- a database

We gave ourselves a 1 month to build something that anyone could use, something a bit more simple to setup than notebooks, but with naas.ai running in the background so users never feels locked in.

It's going to be a real challenge but it fits with our mission : make data science accessible to everyone.

So stay tune, and please share your feedback and ideas. 

PS: today was day 12 of my #66daysofdata challenge, and I played with our LinkedIn drivers to build the chart below.

TITLE: ğŸ â­ï¸ What is the most useful Python statement?
TEXT:
ğŸ â­ï¸ What is the most useful Python statement? 

Arguably the "if/else" is one of the most usedÂ statements in Python. So it might win the "most useful" award ğŸ†

Do you agree?

For those not so familiar with Python, or want a refresherğŸ‘‡

It allows your code to execute a function if a certain condition is met. 
Unlike other languages, you donâ€™t need to use curly braces.

The if-else statement isÂ used to execute both the true part and the false part of a given condition. 

If the condition is true, the if block code is executed and if the condition is false, the else block code is executed.

Here is a very simple example to illustrate visually what it does. 
I really like how simple the syntax is.

If you think there are other statements that are most useful than this one, please share in the comment. ğŸ’¬
I'm curious to see what "else" you have in mind ğŸ˜‡

That's it for today, hope you had a nice Sunday.â˜€ï¸

TITLE: ğŸ ğŸª„ So, what exactly is a magic command in Python?
TEXT:
ğŸ ğŸª„ So, what exactly is a magic command in Python?

When Python first appeared in 1991, it was seen more as an â€œat your own riskâ€ computing language.
In 2018, it became the language #1 on stackoverflow, beating Javascript.
Now, it's the language of reference in data science, machine learning, and software development.

â†’ Magic commands are shortcuts over the usual Python syntax designed to facilitate routine tasks.

There 2 kinds of commands:
- Line magic, denoted by a single % prefix to act on a single line 
- Cell magic, denoted by a doubleÂ %% prefix to act on entire cell or multiple lines of input.

Today, let's look at the %run command. 
ğŸ‘‡
Suppose you are working on a new project onÂ Jupyter, and you wish to use a function that you wrote earlier. 
Rather than copying the entire code into a Jupyter cell, you can use the %run Python magic.

It makes: 
âœ… your notebook more readable 
âœ… your work more reproducible.

This is the technique that got us started with the naas_drivers python library. I will talk about it in later posts. 

Did you know this? Do you find this post useful? 

This was day 4 of my #66daysofdata challenge.

TITLE: ğŸ¤¯ "How to consolidate 2 files with one common column automatically?" is the first business problem that got me digging into python and data science.
TEXT:
ğŸ¤¯ "How to consolidate 2 files with one common column automatically?" is the first business problem that got me digging into python and data science. 


Let's say you are a financial analysts. 

Your job is to analyse weekly sales by product, product category, stores and create reports to your management with key performance indicators (KPIs) 

But you have a problem. 
You have 2 different CSV exports to handle to get to your results.

â†’ File 1 has the list of products ID, product names and product category.

â†’ File 2 has the list of products ID, the value in sales, and the store in which it was sold.

If you use Excel you need to do a VLOOKUP, it can be quite manual. 
If you use SQL you need to do an INNER JOIN, it can be quite tricky if the 2 sources are not in the same database. 

ğŸ If you are using Python, you can use Pandas library and create a consolidation table with a simple formula : 

df = pd.merge(df_1, df_2)

There is absolutely no problem and to repeat this operation over time and it is way faster in most cases than both options listed above. 

BONUS ğŸ‘‡
By doing this operation in Jupyter Notebook,  you can document the process in text and code, to reproduce and share.

But the best thing now, is doing it with naas.ai where you can schedule the import, process the file, and send yourself an email to build a completely automated workflow !! 

â­ï¸ Check out this Naas templates from Oludolapo Oketunji, she contributed to the open source project with a slightly different use case (students, grades) but you will surely understand the idea. 

This was day 2 of my "#66daysofdata with #naas"

TITLE: "Businesses collect a growing amount of data but only a few manage to connect the dots and extract true business value."
TEXT:
"Businesses collect a growing amount of data but only a few manage to connect the dots and extract true business value."
Do you think it's true? ğŸ‘‡

I do.

This major challenge is supposed to be the purpose of data science: to make data useful. Right?

But the main reasons why itâ€™s not happening are the following:

1ï¸âƒ£ Data scientists are hard to find, and supply does not meet industry needs. Too much emphasis on algorithms, and not enough on understanding business problems (aka SME)

2ï¸âƒ£ Infrastructure is expensive to set up and maintain, there are need for a dedicated team of engineers to manage the â€œmodern data stackâ€.

3ï¸âƒ£ Time to value is slow and complex, business needs change fast (almost on daily basis) but technical answer takes weeks to be delivered due to software engineering processes and practices.

This situation creates frictions or even makes impossible the adoption of data science in the organizations that need it the most to create competitive advantage and resiliency in very uncertain times.

We are trying our best to solve that withÂ naas.aiÂ with:

ğŸ–¼ A customizable templates library developed by the growing Naas open source community.

TITLE: Did you know that you can follow all your company metrics in Notion using naas.ai?
TEXT:
Did you know that you can follow all your company metrics in Notion using naas.ai?
Here is how we do itğŸ‘‡


â†’ In Notion, create a database, each page will become a report where you are going to include a chart. 

In the page properties, add fields that will serve as labels + indicators:
- Domain: Marketing, Sales, Operations...
- Period: YTD (Year to date), MTD (Month to date)...
- Scenario: Daily, Weekly, Monthly...
- Value: last know value 
- Var: variation between last known value and last period
- Var% : same than Var but in %
- Target: objective for the current metrics
+ a reference to the template located in Naas (see below). 

Make sure to put your database in gallery mode, group by domain, and on each card, make visible the cover inside page to show the chart and properties you want (Value, Var, Scenario in the example attached) 

â†’ In Naas, make sure you create one template for each metrics you want to follow, use Naas notion driver to connect to the database and start updating pages automatically. 

In the notebook template: 
- write the business logic as you see fit
- if it makes sense add a bit of ML to predict, cluster your data.
- create a chart and use Naas asset feature to expose it
- update notion database and add Naas template URL in a field
- add a Naas scheduler feature to refresh automatically

Do you find this content useful?
If you need help to implement it for your company â†’ Let's talk ğŸ¤™

TITLE: 6 Open source libraries for data visualization in Python, and why they are unique ğŸ‘‡
TEXT:
6 Open source libraries for data visualization in Python, and why they are unique ğŸ‘‡

What's your favorite? 


ğŸ“Š Matplotlib
matplotlibÂ is the O.G. of Python data visualization libraries. Despite being over a decade old, it's still the most widely used library for plotting in the Python community.Â 

ğŸŒŠ Seaborn
SeabornÂ harnesses the power of matplotlib to create beautiful charts in a few lines of code. With its styles and color palettes, Seaborn is more aesthetically pleasing and modern.

9ï¸âƒ£ Plotnine
Plotnine is a python implementation ofÂ ggplot2, an R plotting system, and concepts fromÂ The Grammar of Graphics (the foundation book for producing impactful graphs ğŸ“•) 

ğŸŒ» Bokeh
Like ggplot,Â BokehÂ is based onÂ The Grammar of Graphics, but unlike ggplot, it's native to Python. Its strength lies in the ability to create interactive, web-ready plots, which can be easily output as JSON objects, HTML documents, or interactive web applications + streaming and real-time data.

ğŸ“‰ Plotly
You might know Plotly as an online platform for data visualization, but did you also know you can access its capabilities from a Python notebook? We have quite a few examples on naas.ai templates library 

â†’ This one is my favorite as they appeal more to business users IMHO ğŸ’š

ğŸ¤™ Holoviz
HoloViz is built on top ofÂ Bokeh,Â Matplotlib, andÂ Plotly's. It also enables you to create an incredible dashboard using the Panel framework. 

â†’ I want to explore this as I keep seeing Marc Skov Madsen, PhD, CFA amazing posts, but I have no time these daysğŸ˜…

So ğŸ‘‡
If you want to contribute to the naas.ai templates library on any of those Python libraries, you are welcome. 

- barchart
- linechart
- barlinechart
- horizontalbarchart
- waterfall
- map 
- heatmap 
....there are plenty of templates to do!

Check out what we have already done with Plotly and feel free to join our community. 
We are building a very useful open source data science templates library ğŸ’š

TEXT:

Now, there is a Naas template for thatğŸ‘‡

ğŸ”´ If you are like me, you receive news every day in your mailbox.
But sometimes, they are not relevant at all!
You end up losing your time.

âœ… What if instead of data being pushed to you, you would pull it from newsAPI. org and select the exact topics your want to follow?

â†’ This is exactly what this template does.

News API is a simple HTTP REST API for searching and retrieving live articles from all over the web.

It can help you answer questions like:
- What top stories is TechCrunch running right now?
- What new articles were published about the next iPhone today?
- Has my company or product been mentioned or reviewed by any blogs recently?

You can search for articles with any combination of the following criteria:
- Keyword or phrase
- Date published
- Source domain name
- Language

With Naas notification, scheduling feature, HTML drivers, this template is a good alternative to a simpleÂ GoogleNews alert that you cannot custom.

I use it to follow the news with the keywords: "data, automation, AI"
It serves me every day.

TITLE: ğŸ“Š Want to create bar-line chart and share it with a URL?
TEXT:
ğŸ“Š Want to create bar-line chart and share it with a URL?
With this Naas templatesğŸ‘‡ You can do it in less than 1min.

Bar-Line chartsÂ are great because they enable you to show two metric values aggregated across a group dimension. 
They are useful for showing quantity alongside changes in trends over time. 

Today during naas.ai Community Call, we wanted to do a template contribution from A - Z, and this is the topic we worked on. 

ğŸ”´ Problem (Issue on GitHub)
As a business user, I want to see a graph with a 2 y-axis. This can show for example the evolution and variation of sales.
- one is a line with a trend
- one is a bar with variation 
I want to share it easily and iterate quickly.

âœ… Solution (Pull Request)
A notebook divided into 3 parts:Â 
- Input: setup data frame with one column with DATE, VALUE, VAR 
- Model: create the chart from the python library
- Output: generate PNG and HTML files via URL link via Naas asset feature

You can now use and customize this template, plug different inputs into it...no need to go to Stack Overflow or the Plotly documentation...everything is ready to use.

click on "Open in Naas",

TITLE: Templates are the keys ğŸ”‘ to true data science democratization.
TEXT:
Templates are the keys ğŸ”‘ to true data science democratization.
Why? 

Because when it comes to data, Business needs change fast...
and Tech answers take time to be delivered. 

That's a fact. 
â†’ Good technical solutions for specific business problems do not just fall from trees. ğŸŒ´

The thesis for years has been to empower business people with "no-code" tech solutions.
But, the truth is that you are quickly limited by the design of those solutions. 

ğŸ¤– ğŸ“£ Until we manage to just talk to your computer and get the exact answer we need like with Jarvis in Iron Man (and we can get there with NLP I believe), we need to figure out another way. 

It's been years that I am iterating on this,

â†’ the most actionable solution I found is to build meaningful low-code data science templates, that even people with non-tech knowledge can use, on very precise use cases.

This is why what we focus on at naas.ai, with the core team and a community of awesome data science template creators.

With Naas data science templates, you can:
- automate workflows 
- created graphs, reports, dashboards 
- include AI/ML where it's needed to upgrade human capabilities

Want to learn how to build and promote data science templates? 

Join us tomorrow for our Naas Community Call, 
and let's geek out ğŸ¤™

TITLE: Regular people, those without â€œdataâ€ in their title, are central to all data-related work.
TEXT:
Regular people, those without â€œdataâ€ in their title, are central to all data-related work. 

Data teams must:

â†’ work with those regular people every day,
â†’develop a feel for their problems and opportunities,
â†’ embrace their hopes and fears surrounding data,

Then only focus on equipping people with the tools they need to formulate and solve their own problems.

They should also ask two questions with each data project:
1) Who will this effect?
2) How can we get them involved as soon as possible? (disclaimer: ASAP)

â˜ï¸
This is, in a nutshell, what this brilliant article fromÂ Tom Redman, the "Data doc" is saying. (link in the comment)

And I could not agree more.
This is what we strive for atÂ naas.ai, the business user is at the center of our Notebook templates approach because he is the final destination of the work. He is the juge and jury.

â­ï¸ Even if we help data literate folks, data engineers, scientist get things up and running faster, the goal is always to serve somebody else.

TITLE: ğŸš¨ Managing a Product Roadmap is super HARD! Yet crucial if you want to provide value.
TEXT:
ğŸš¨ Managing a Product Roadmap is super HARD! Yet crucial if you want to provide value.

Here are 6 things I learned while building naas.ai.ğŸ‘‡

1ï¸âƒ£ Product Vision
This is critical as it sets the path to creating a meaningful product. 
This initial vision doesnâ€™t have to be the final one but it starts the process.

â†’ Naas Product Vision is to turn Jupyter Notebooks into Services to apply data science in the daily jobs of anyone, using low-code templates.
That's what Naas stands for: âš¡ï¸Data Science Notebooks as a Service.


2ï¸âƒ£ Strategy
This is the case you build for your product. You want internal and external stakeholders to know the overall business goal of the project. 

â†’ Naas strategy is to create the most useful Data science templates library in the market. "You have a data problem, there is a Naas template for that" ğŸ;)


3ï¸âƒ£ Requirements
Understand what's vital for users. Know how your end-users feel about current products, what they are looking for, and if they need feature requests. 

â†’ We started by scheduling Notebooks using minimal lines of code. But then, saw the need to "not start from scratch every time" was bigger. This is why we are now building templates with the community.ğŸŒ


4ï¸âƒ£ Product Plan
It is the way the plan is going to be executed as the project moves forward. Prioritize and set specific goals on this timeline, but let room for innovation and flexibility.

â†’ As Naas mission is to build templates on a variety of use cases, things can becoming overwhelming pretty quick. That's why we: 
- define priority domains (content, marketing, sales...) 
- score the template by impact (how many people can use it) ğŸ’š


5ï¸âƒ£ Markers
These are important when it comes to keeping everyone in the loop about timing. While you might not have exact dates, knowing where the markers are to track progress is essential to keep moving forward. 

â†’ We have a "âœ¨ What's new?" update on Notion accessible via our website but there is still room for improvement to make it more actionable.


6ï¸âƒ£ Metrics
Make sure the metrics are clear and that everyone is measuring things in the same way. Everyone needs to be talking in the same language so there is no question around what is being measured.

â†’ Some metrics are pretty easy: number of templates available, by domain... But our ambition is to build a virtuous circle where we can mesure value created and reward contributors for that via our credit system. ğŸ’°WIP


To sum it up, if you build a product roadmap, focus on : 
- Product Vision 
- Strategy 
- Requirements
- Product Plan 
- Markers 
- Metrics


Do you find this post useful?
If you do please like and comment for more power âš¡ï¸

And, don't forget to share the open source love ! ğŸ’š

TITLE: In data science, there is a lot of people building microwaves, making recipes...but very few people serving the food ğŸ½ğŸ¤¤
TEXT:
In data science, there is a lot of people building microwaves, making recipes...but very few people serving the food ğŸ½ğŸ¤¤

And this is a BIG problem.âŒ

How can any chef of decent restaurant assess the quality of his work without servers getting feedback from clients on the food he makes? 

99% of the time, the client is completely clueless on how the food has been made. 

Still, he can judge if the food: 
- filled his stomac
- tasted good  
- made him want to come back again, and talk about it

â†’ I really believe it's the same in data science. 

99% of the time, the end user will only care about your work if: 
- it answers a business problem 
- the output looks nice and clear
- the story is told in a way that it can be remembered and shared

In short, data science folks should embrace "decision intelligence": a discipline that augments data science with theory from social science, decision theory, and managerial science.

This allegory of the people building microwaves vs serving dishes has been coined by Cassie Kozyrkov (Chief Decision Scientist at Google) during her "Making Friends with Machine Learning" series. 

For me, it's a true masterpiece, and I could not agree more. 
I hope this post still aligns with the original author idea :)

What is your point view? 

Does it makes sense?

Support that post with ğŸ‘ or ğŸ’¬ in the comment if you find it interesting. 

And don't forget to share the open source love ğŸ’š

If you are like me, you have reasons, purpose, energy...

TITLE: Data scientists all have the same problem.
TEXT:
Data scientists all have the same problem.

If they don't manage to make an impact, it's because they did not:

1. Scoped the business problem properly 
2. Proposed a simple and fast solution to the problem
3. Iterated to improve the solution with their audience 

If you do not succeed to get the buy-in of your audience as a data scientist, ask yourself how you could optimize those 3 points.

Some ideas:

- ask more questions to your audience about the problem to be solve 
- make sure your understand them very clearly, feel their pain
- create trust, build a relationship: "we are on the same side"
- communicate with them every time you are working 
- share your doubts, ask more questions if needed
- get things done quick and ask for feedback
- work on the quality of the output
- define the distribution mode
- create content with them

And the most important : don't ever give up.
âš¡ï¸ğŸ’š

TITLE: â¤ï¸ğŸ What did make you fall in love with Python language?
TEXT:
â¤ï¸ğŸ What did make you fall in love with Python language? 

StorytimeğŸ‘‡

Guido van Rossum created it in the late 1980s at Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica (CWI) in the Netherlands ğŸ‡³ğŸ‡±.

It was capable of exception handling and interfacing with the Amoeba operating system. 

Its implementation began in December 1989.
(The month I came on this earth ğŸ¼ğŸ‘¶ğŸ˜…)

When he began implementing Python, Guido van Rossum was also reading the published scripts from â€œMonty Python's Flying Circusâ€, a BBC comedy series from the 1970s.Â 

Van Rossum thought he needed a name that was short, unique, and slightly mysterious, so he decided to call the language Python.

THAT WAS IT.
30+ years later,  Python is the most popular programming language available becauseÂ it has simplified syntax gave emphasis on natural language. 

ğŸ‘‰ I don't come from a tech background, I'm a creative, I love art, history, music, philosophy, so I think this direction toward natural language is why I love Python so much. ğŸ’šğŸ’šğŸ’š

But even if python codes can be easily written and executed much faster than other programming languages : you still need to write it. 

And I have to admit, I'm a bad Python writer. 

My thing is reading and finding the right way to make machines work for you with minimal number of characters. 

I find this magical.

ğŸ‘‰ This is why I'm so pumped to work every single day on a project that aims at making beautiful Python Notebook templates to fix very specific problems. 

I'm grateful to work with an amazing naas.ai team and community. 

ğŸ‘ğŸ’¬ I'm curious to learn more about you and what did make you fall in love  with Python in the comment. 

Have a nice weekend everyone !

Cheers.

If you do, you may know about "no-code" solutions like Zapier to do that.

A typical workflow can look like this: 
If â†’ a new page/item is created in your Notion database.

What I liked the most about this very friendly conversation is the energy and passion she has for the field.Â 

I asked her only 3 simple questions:Â 

1) What's your story?Â 

2) What's your drive and mission?

3) What's your views of the future?Â 

...and in less than 40min we covered a lot.

We talked about:
- the beginning of Databricks 
- how she pro-actively worked with her clients to ensure success and adoption
- how she pushed internally for new features, based on users feedback
- why we are still at the very early stages of data science, and what is yet to come.
...and much more.

Thank you so muchÂ ViniÂ for this very cool session!

TITLE: â° When you are scheduling your notebooks in naas.ai, this is what happens:
TEXT:
â° When you are scheduling your notebooks in naas.ai, this is what happens:

1) A copy of the notebook you are working on is sent to the production folder.
2) A â€œcronâ€ task is registered in the Naas manager to know when to run it.

Then, the whole notebook will be executed.

As simple as that. 

Curious to try it out? 

Use a Naas template to send yourself a reminder by email everyday....to share what you are working on LinkedIn for example. (This is what I do) ğŸ˜‡

TITLE: ğŸ´â€â˜ ï¸âš¡ï¸ Are you interested in data science hackathons? We are thinking about building one powered by naas.ai
TEXT:
ğŸ´â€â˜ ï¸âš¡ï¸ Are you interested in data science hackathons? We are thinking about building one powered by naas.ai

But if we do it, it's to create solutions that will go into production on DAY 1 and could be reusable by the entire data community. 

Most hackathons I've seen come with some problems (apart from not being reusable because it's about speed and not quality ğŸ¥²): 

1) There are not enough experts available to help the teams.

2) Sources and data are not easy to access. 

3) Venue and technical equipment are not the same for everyone. 

4) There are no clear conditions and deadlines.

5) Teams may lack of confidence.


Do you agree? 

Please share your experience in the comment, and if you would be interested in taking part in it. 

We would love to do this in the coming weeks/months but we want to do it right. 

All your feedback and advice will help so thanks for your support ğŸ‘ and comments ğŸ’¬. 

Have a nice weekend everyone.

TEXT:
ğŸ™ Do you know Deepak John Reji? I got the pleasure to be one of his podcast guests a few days ago. 

He is building an amazing series around data, Machine Learning and AI.

It always feels a bit strange when someone ask you questions during a 1:1 interview.
You need to structure your thoughts to be as clear as possible.
You don't have questions from the audience. 

It's also hard to have honest feedback, so if you have time to listen to this and share what you think. That would be awesome. âš¡ï¸ğŸ™ 

You don't need to listen to everything !ğŸ˜

Deepak did a very accurate breakdown the different topics we talked about using Youtube timestamp in the description. 
â†’ It makes it very easy to pick what you are the most interested in earring about ğŸ˜‡
 
Here are the list of the topics discussed:

- Why Notebook as a service?
- Advantages of using AI Notebooks in production
- Importance of low-code platforms in modern data science
- Importance of impact and explainability
- How can Naas make it easier to monitor the overall process deployment of an AI solution
- Naas Integration with different data sources
- Naas design concept of Features, drivers & templates
- Naas Scheduling capability
- Naas Asset Sharing features and its challenges
-Future of Naas

I hope you find this interesting. 

Have a nice Sunday! â˜€ï¸

Humanity is at stake.

TITLE: ğŸ¤“  Me and my team at naas.ai are complete outsiders in the data science game...and we recently understood it doesn't  matter.
TEXT:
ğŸ¤“  Me and my team at naas.ai are complete outsiders in the data science game...and we recently understood it doesn't  matter.

Benefits: independence, observation and creativity! 


For a long time, we looked up at all the incredible data science entrepreneurs, ex- Google, Amazon, Netflix, Microsoft, Meta, Databricks, Airbnb, LinkedIn....

We were not feeling very legit launching our "Notebook as a service" platform. 
I guess we were under the "imposter syndrome".

Because we were not coming from the Valley, because we had fewer resources and less time to build it...we invented a new way to turn our Project Jupyter Notebooks into production data engines, using low-code formulas.

We did not re-invent the wheel, we tried to upgrade it to fix our problems.
We first used the product for ourselves, then open sourced it. 
And it raised some interest :)

Now we have the opportunity to meet and talk to those incredible people we were looking up to. 

ğŸ‘‡
Being outsiders has given us compassion for others who are left out. 
This gives us a different perspective. 

This is why we now want to create the most inclusive community of data science templates creators ğŸ’š and build the most amazing library of awesome data science templates. 

Starting tomorrow, we will start creating more content on the 250+ templates already available.

If you want to support us you can : 
- Like this post and share your best feedback and emoji in the comment âš¡ï¸
- Star the awesome-notebooks repository on Github â­ï¸
- Like our LinkedIn page and Youtube channel. 

All the links will be in the 1st comment. 
Thanks a lot. Spread the open source love. 

Cheers ğŸ¤™

TITLE: People don't understand charts ğŸ“Š. â†’ ğŸ’£
TEXT:
People don't understand charts ğŸ“Š. â†’ ğŸ’£

Charts are a big part of modern life. They are increasingly essential to our work, theÂ media we consume, and the apps we use to track the way we exercise, eat, and sleep.

They are even more important in business. ğŸ’°
Itâ€™s important to choose the right type of chart for the right job. 
This might sound simple, but itâ€™s not. 

Tools that help visualize complex data have become incredibly sophisticated (Microsoft Power BI, Tableau, Looker...)
But fantastic visualizations that are interactive, animated, and complex might not be right for your needs.

In my opinion, there are 2 types of charts that serve 2 different purposes:
- Allow viewers to explore data, 
- Communicate insights quickly and clearly. 

Both are effective, but only when theyâ€™re used with the right audiences for the right reasons.

â†’ This is NOT a trivial matter. A lack of ability to interpret charts makes people more susceptible to being misled = they will NOT trust the data.

So what should we do about that? 

I believe that AI + NLP can lead us to a new era of data communication.  

Where people that are not "data literate", but know how to read & speak, can interact in a much more human way with the data. 

It might be as simple as traffic lights and a little sentence to help them decide the actions they need to take:
 
ğŸ”´  â†’ Red: "something is wrong, move your a** and do more X" 
ğŸŸ   â†’ Orange: "you are borderline, don't lower your efforts on Y"
ğŸŸ¢  â†’ Green: "you are doing great, keep pushing on Z"

...And it might not be on all the metrics, micro-decisions can be taken by the machines. 
Big tech companies are already there. But what about the rest?

I had a brilliant conversation with Somil Gupta about this topic when I presented him our roadmap for naas.ai earlier today. 

A new narrative needs to be created so that the masses understand what AI can do for them. 


What do you think? 
Does what you just read make sense to you??


PS1: we are building naas.ai with an amazing open source community of notebook creators (not only tech), and we need more help, join us on Slack with the link below ğŸ‘‡ 
PS2: if you are a business and want to learn more about how our community can help you. You can reach me at jeremy@naas.ai ğŸ’Œ

TITLE: ğŸ‘âš¡ï¸ Everyone should learn code, even non-tech, it's like a foreign language, just pick the one that suits best your aspirations :) You may not speak it all the time but you will know what your are "talking about"
TEXT:
ğŸ‘âš¡ï¸ Everyone should learn code, even non-tech, it's like a foreign language, just pick the one that suits best your aspirations :) You may not speak it all the time but you will know what your are "talking about" 

Good post from Carly ğŸ° T. 

At naas.ai, we are building open source data science templates using notebooks + low-code formulas so that even if you are not a data scientist, you can use data science. 

The idea is that you don't start from 0.

â†’ You can just run the template (with minimal tech knowledge) to make things work. 

â†’ But if you want to go deeper (and you should):
You have the code. 
You have the power. 

No blackbox on how things work. Customize it to your need.

TITLE: âš¡ï¸ğŸ“Š We are done. It's over.
TEXT:
âš¡ï¸ğŸ“Š We are done. It's over.
And here is why. 

Storytime:

naas.ai is entering a new phase. 

In March 2020, my associates and I at CashStory started the R&D on the Naas.ai platform: a secured and managed Jupyter Notebook infrastructure in Amazon Web Services (AWS) with added micro-services, to run Notebooks in production.

This quest was inspired by:
â†’ our need for fast data delivery and iteration,
â†’ the work of Netflix data team, betting heavily on Notebooks to solve their internal data challenges,
â†’ our feeling that most of the Python code in our scripts could be abstracted like an Excel formula, to make it reusable and "low-code".

With our little resources, we choose to build it in "bootstrap" mode while working on our consulting gigs with historical Corporate clients.

Last year, we launched and open-sourced the MVP, and it did not turn out so bad if we check our metrics:
ğŸ”‚ 6 low-code features
ğŸ 35 low-code drivers
ğŸ’š +50 contributors 
ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» +2000 free accounts 
ğŸŒ +70 countries 
ğŸ˜ +200 templates 
ğŸš€ +300 people on Slack 
ğŸ’° +400 business leads identified...and a few paying already.
â­ï¸ +1200 stars on Github
âš¡ï¸ +3700 commits on Github
ğŸ¤– +10k jobs created 
ğŸ—“ +500k events managed 
and almost ğŸ’¬ 1m views on social media

But the truth is we were not able to focus enough because we were dealing with 2 business activities: 
- Consulting
- Product

And one was way more scalable than the other.

We understood from Naas first users and contributors that what is really missing in data science is "collective intelligence repository", an open-source catalog of Notebook templates:
- built by the community
- ready to use
- solving real business challenges.

The idea is simple: whether you are a tech or non-tech, if you have a data problem to solve, there should be a template for that. ğŸğŸ˜‰

Notebook templates can indeed be the building blocks of a true data science democratization. 

Templates can normalize the way humans make decisions (based on an agreed set of standards) and get assisted by AI, without losing on explainability or the ability to customize logic.

ğŸ‘‡
This is why today, we are:
âœ… officially saying goodbye to our previous activity: CashStory, while it will remain the company name, we will now operate only under Naas.ai
âœ… launching the last product update of the Naas MVP phase: read the full update with the link in the first comment for full details.

If you relate to anything I've written above. 
Or if you just want to support this move. 

Please like or comment below for more power âš¡ï¸âš¡ï¸ğŸ’šğŸ’š

Cheers everybody. Have a nice week ahead.

PS: We're working hard to build Naas, and need more help! If you know anybody who would like to contribute to open source - in engineering, marketing roles, and more - please let us know and tell your friends!

TITLE: Want to schedule your Jupyter Notebook with minimum effort?Â naas.aiÂ is the place to do it.
TEXT:
Want to schedule your Jupyter Notebook with minimum effort?Â naas.aiÂ is the place to do it. 

You just need to add this simple formulağŸ‘‡

import naas
naas.scheduler.add(cron="0 * * * *") â† this cron argument is the standard synthax worldwide. It means every hour in that case.

Press play â–¶ï¸ and your Notebook will be sent to the Naas "âš¡ï¸Production folder".

ğŸš€ DONE. 

Now, if you want to follow the execution, go to the "Naas" section â†’ "Manager" 

All the important information is over there: 
- Jobs 
- Events
- Usage 

-------
I'm writing this today as someone asked me the question in private. 

This is an extract of Naas White Paper (coming soon) with text and a schema, definitely more technical. But feel free to share your thoughts and feedback. 

1) A user works on a sandbox notebook connecting to sources
2) He adds to his sandbox notebook a Naas low-code formula to run it in production
3) Naas runner receives an HTTP request from the low-code formula with parameters, log the event or return an error to the sandbox notebook, and save the jobs.json file
4) Each time a Naas runner receives a new HTTP request, he saves a version of the notebook as history and considers the current version as the source notebook for execution."


PS 1:  Do you feel like reading/reviewing our White Paper before we release it? That would be awesome â†’ Just comment a ğŸ‘ and I will send it to you in private.

PS 2: Spread the open source love always ğŸ’š

TITLE: ğŸŒ If you want to understand how the world works, there's no better way to start than data science.
TEXT:
ğŸŒ If you want to understand how the world works, there's no better way to start than data science.
But here is the thing ğŸ‘‡


To understand the world, you need metrics.

And, there is no standard in the way metrics should be built.

Even worse,Â Project JupyterÂ Notebooks: the de-facto standard document to do data science, can get really messy.

This is why, exactly one year ago, we created a very simple framework.

Each time we build a Notebook, we make sure it follows the following structure:
- A clear title with "Tool - Purpose of the Notebook"Â 
- "Input" section listing all your variables (secret keys, filters...)
- "Model" section to store all the transformations applied to the data 
(if possible, create reusable functions)
- "Output" section that takes care of all way the content that can be created (csv, xls, chart in png...)

+ we use as much markdown as necessary to make sure anyone can understand what's going on.


âš¡ï¸We are now working toward a new version of this repository with our open source community.

â†’ This new version will focus on making it very simple to access private and public metrics.

...and hopefully, make data science much easier!


I will talk about it more in the coming days. I'm feeling really down these days with this war on Ukraine, so I hope this will bring me more energy ğŸ’š ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¦

I hope you guys are going OK...?

Make sure to followÂ #naaslifeÂ and click on the bell in my profileÂ JÃ©rÃ©my RavenelÂ to get notified on what's next.

PS: check all our templates in the Naas awesome-notebooks repository + join us on slack if you want to help. (Links in the comment)

TITLE: ğŸ“Š Metric vs KPI vs OKR = do you know the difference?
TEXT:
ğŸ“Š Metric vs KPI vs OKR = do you know the difference?

These terms are often used interchangeably as if they all mean the same thing...they do not.


(1) A metric is a tool to measure something.

Examples:
- Monthly Active Users
- Churn Rate
- Net Promoter Score
- EBIT
- Cashflow
- Burn rate


(2) A KPI is a tool to keep track of how a key area of your business is performing. A KPI always contains a metric to measure the performance of that key area.

A KPI consists of the following elements:
- Metric
- Current value
- Target value
- Title


(3) Key Result always belongs to an Objective (OKR). It's a tool to positively impact the performance of a certain metric. A Key Result also makes use of a metric.

â†’ Very similar to KPI, except that a Key Result always has a target value that is different from the start value to measure success.

A Key Result consists of the following components:
- Metric
- Current value
- Start value
- Target value
- Title


ğŸŸ¢ Metric vs KPI vs OKR can be slightly confusing, since there is some overlap between them...it's ok if you did not know. 

I'm curious though. 

Question: How much time per week in total do you think is spent (average) on updating Metric, KPI, OKR in organizations? 

Is that : 
â° 1 hour
â° 10 hours 
â° Much more than 10 hours

PS: this is not a poll, just an invitation to comment :) Cheers.
#opensourceÂ #dataÂ #moderndatastackÂ #creatorsÂ #consumersÂ #datascienceÂ #futureofworkÂ #buildinpublicÂ #naaslife #metrics #okr #kpi #business #success

TITLE: ğŸ’” I believe a link is missing between data science creators and consumers.
TEXT:
ğŸ’” I believe a link is missing between data science creators and consumers.

Ready to read why?

A decade afterÂ The EconomistÂ warned us weâ€™d all soon be drowning in data, the â€œmodern data stackâ€ is emerging as Silicon Valleyâ€™s proposed life raft.

= a new framework to move data around an organization and make it available for people to use and analyze.Â 

The framework has 3 key elements:Â 
- Ingestion: writes data from a wide variety of sources into a central warehouse
- Transformation: models that data in the warehouse, converting it from raw material to usable components.
- Visualization: provides direct access to data so that it can be visualized and analyzed, also known as BI (Business Intelligence)

It isÂ inspiring conferences,Â articles,Â how-to guides, andÂ companies themselves and a lot of new companies are looking to define their niche in this booming ecosystem.
The issue is, we don't need yet another data tool, we arenâ€™t lacking foundational elements.Â 

â†’ Except one, the metrics layer.

People in the industry are so absorbed by the tech, that they are missing out on the very simple needs of decision-makers (ie data consumers)

To make those decisions, they need to know whatâ€™s happening.Â 
No fancy AI algorithm; just a simple narrator, telling people whatâ€™s going on.Â 

Am I in the ğŸ”´ ? the ğŸŸ¢? or the ğŸŸ  on this indicator?Â 
Why?Â 
What should I do?

While it may seem "easy" to answer this question, it is not. This is where data science can help.

â†’ The core problem is that thereâ€™s no central repository for defining a metric.
ğŸ’š To bridge the gap we need to make them globally accessible to every other tool in the data stack.Â 

So that data science creators can do their best work at finding patterns.Â 
And data consumers do the same at transforming those patterns into actions.Â 

ğŸ˜‡ I believe Project Jupyter Notebooks, when operated as metric logic engines can bridge this gap.Â 

Classic software engineering processes cannot keep up with the speed of the business, parameters are constantly added/removed to their decision-making process but Notebook can provide this level of agility.

At naas.ai, we are approaching this problem with Notebook templates, created by an awesome open source community, that wants to solve companies' and society's most challenging issues with data.Â 


Does this post make sense for you?


PS: this text and image are inspired by the very interesting article of Benn Stancil "The missing piece of the modern data stack", check out the full article in the comment.
#opensource #data #moderndatastack #creators #consumers #datascience #futureofwork #buildinpublic #naaslife

TITLE: â›”ï¸ğŸ§  Companies need to save the brainpower of their employees to create the future, not repeat what has been done in the past !!Â
TEXT:
â›”ï¸ğŸ§  Companies need to save the brainpower of their employees to create the future, not repeat what has been done in the past !!Â 

Automation, analytics, and AI, if they are well used and interconnected, can scale human work by 10x, easy. 

Not replace. Scale.

We are in the so-called  "4th Industrial Revolution", but I still see so many businesses stuck in the 3rd desperately trying to automate processes.

What want to do is optimize costs.
I believe they have to wrong approach.

This (r)evolution isÂ changing how we live, work, and communicate. It's reshaping government, education, healthcare, and commerce â€”almost every aspect of life. 

â†’ It also changes the things we value and the way we value them.

Like Justin Welsh rightfully said in his post today, "The great resignation is growing faster than ever", and it's all over the globe. My take is that: ğŸ‘‡

ğŸ”´ Nobody wants to work a 9 to 5 where they repeat the tasks they have done yesterday. 

ğŸŸ¢ People don't want to work hard, they want to work smart. 
They are OK to scale their work with bots that can repeat what they previously did manually, to figure out what can be improved and act upon! 

They want to bring value not only to the companies, but to society. 

âš¡ï¸ Moral of the story:

Work for the future, not for yesterday.
Work differently.

Do you agree?


PS: at naas.ai we are building data science templates for the 4IR decision-making networks using Project Jupyter. If you are familiar with Notebooks, join our community of creators with the link in the comment ğŸ˜‡âš¡ï¸

TITLE: Unbelievable. Today, Iâ€™m at Netflix HQ. Presenting naas.ai
TEXT:
Unbelievable. Today, Iâ€™m at Netflix HQ. Presenting naas.ai 

I have been invited for lunch by a Top Executive and will follow by a meeting with the person in charge of the Notebook Infrastructure - the Data Platform Edge. 

Iâ€™m beyond excited to present them the work we have done with the community on Jupyter Notebooks templates (we call them awesome-notebooks) and the low-code formulas that turns notebooks into data engines. 

Itâ€™s even more crazy that their #opensource projects and publications has inspired us in the first place!

TITLE: ğŸš¨âš¡ï¸Building Skills in Data Science Is Hard.
TEXT:
ğŸš¨âš¡ï¸Building Skills in Data Science Is Hard.

Finding the job that fits you, is even harder. 

If you want to succeed in your journey to become an accomplished data professional, you need to stay focused.

But how can you when there are so many "labels" a data professional can have? 
â†’ Data Scientist
â†’ Data Analyst
â†’ Data Engineer 
â†’ Data Architect
â†’ Data Storyteller
â†’ Machine Learning Scientist
â†’ Machine Learning Engineer

This can derail your focus. 

+ The time youâ€™re spending learning specific languages, frameworks, tools is time youâ€™re not spending working on real business use cases.

A lot of data professionals have "context switching" issues...and context switching is the death of deep work.

I have these issues as well :p

This is why I try to be careful about criticisms and suggestions that may throw me off the vision and brand purpose we're building with the naas.ai core team and open source community.

So before putting your time into something new, make sure your vision and brand purpose are clearly defined, communicated and aligned with your dream job.

â­ï¸ Mine is to "democratize access to data, automation & AI"
...and I don't see a better place to be, than where I am right now to do it. 

What about you?
ğŸ‘‰ How would you define your vision and "brand" purpose?

TITLE: ğŸš¨ #Web3: the new buzzword of the decade?
TEXT:
ğŸš¨ #Web3: the new buzzword of the decade? 

Web3 on LinkedIn, Web3 on Instagram, Web3 on Twitter...Web3 everywhere.
â†’ But whatâ€™s this Web3? 

(no the answer is not as simple as 'the evolution of Web2' ğŸ˜‡)

A bit of history:

1ï¸âƒ£ Web1 (90s to mid-2000s) is a 1 dimension internet.
You can only READ information.

2ï¸âƒ£ Web2 (mid-2000s to late 2010s) is a 2 dimensions internet. 
You can READ and WRITE information (post your own content so other people or users can read yours, and vice versa...)

3ï¸âƒ£ Web3 (early 2020s and beyond) is an internet that is not only three-dimensional but potentially, multi-dimensional. Thus, Meta (aka Facebook) with its Metaverse.
You can READ, WRITE, and EXECUTE contracts.

It's like a decentralized stock exchange....for everything. 

âš¡ï¸ What do you think about it? Did you already invest in Web3 with crypto, NFT? 
Curious to learn more and exchange ideas. 

For those who want to take this subject further, I really recommend the book "Token Economy" by Shermin Voshgir on that topic. 

I hope you find this interesting ğŸ‘‡
Cheers.

#token #economy #data #web3 #decentralization #blockchain #ethereum #automation #ai

TITLE: "In community we trust" ğŸ™
TEXT:
"In community we trust" ğŸ™ 
Check out this very interesting article fromÂ Red Hat's CTO about Open source software and supply chain security.ğŸ‘‡

ğŸ˜‡ Open Source is everywhere, and is only going to grow. 
ğŸ‘¿ So does the number bad actors coming with new threats...

The truth is that "The software supply chain is fragile."

â†’ Open source means everyone can see what youâ€™re doing, they can also verify and validate your software and security protocols.

â†’ But how do you secure a supply chain for a product that has no physical form, no box to lock, and is created in an environment where anyone can contribute to it?

âš¡ï¸Chris Wright is giving here some insights on what Redhat is building for the community:  "Thoth" an AI to analyze and recommend software stacks for Python applications with an initial focus on data science use cases

I'm going to deep dive into this since it's a JupyterLab plugin (maybe soon in naas.ai)âš¡ï¸

To all my #datascientists friends, If you read until here, I have a question :

--- How do you approach security in your dev & production workflow?

TITLE: ğŸ‘"Notebooks are great because they can put tech and non-tech people literally on the same page."
TEXT:
ğŸ‘"Notebooks are great because they can put tech and non-tech people literally on the same page."

â†’ Do you agree?  

If you don't know what a "notebook" is, theÂ "Jupyter Notebook" (full name)Â is a web-based interactive computing platform. It combines live code, equations, narrative text, visualizations. 

Notebooks are at the core of every data platform today: Microsoft, Google, Amazon,  DataRobot, Databricks, Dataiku...
Yet, they are integrated into quite complex tools to make them "production-ready" = usable by the business.

âš¡ï¸ At naas.ai, we believe that democratization of Data Science will come from democratization of notebooks as universal data layer for individuals and companies, not only programmers.

We took a very "grassroot" approach to make notebooks accessible by creating low-code formulas (like Excel formulas) and templates that abstract complexity to focus on the value created. 

â†’ Let's democratize Data Science so "nobody thinks data scientists are smarter or better at math than an average person." cc Daliana Liu ğŸ˜‡

Naas comes with a free account = 5$ of credits/month to use notebooks like robots. 

Try us out :) We will be happy to get you on board!
