TITLE: ğŸ’š 52 contributors
TEXT:
ğŸ’š 52 contributors
ğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» +1500 users
ğŸŒ +70 countries
ğŸ¤– +10k jobs created
ğŸ—“ +500k events managed
âš¡ï¸ 3701 commits on Github
...
This post is about naas.ai 1st year ğŸ‚, and where we are goingğŸ‘‡

2021 was a big first year for us, but there's one thing that shines a bit brighter than the rest: theÂ #community ğŸ’šâš¡ï¸. 

It's pretty amazing to see how the idea of using Jupyter notebooks to create an Open Source â€œall-in-one data platformâ€ has received a warm welcome. 

We're so grateful for this support. ğŸ™

As a company,Â our mission is to give the power of making data products to everyone, not just programmers. 
To give you the tool to build your own tools, here are the biggest ways we improved Naas in 2021:

1ï¸âƒ£ Naas is easier to use.
Experience in the Naas manager has been improved and the Production folder became visible in your file system. This way, you can see where your notebooks and files are sent to be scheduled, exposed, triggered to create data products.

2ï¸âƒ£ Naas is more transparent.
Track your credits in the Naas manager, and know exactly the cost of running data products in the cloud. If you are using the Freemium account, it comes with 100 credits, equivalent to 5$ of power to use every month.

3ï¸âƒ£ Naas integrates with more of your tools.
Enjoy powerful low-code integrations with Naas drivers on: Google Sheet, Airtable, LinkedIn, Hubspot, Youtube, Qonto, Plotly charts...
And the most required of all Notion: itâ€™s now very easy to get, and send data, content, and graphs. Naas will become your powerful data back-end for Notion in 2022.

4ï¸âƒ£ Naas templates are easier to create, discover and use.
Contributing to Naas awesome-notebooks templates became very simple. And when you're not sure what to build, you can open browse and download templates from Naas manager by clicking on the â€œOpen in Naasâ€ button.


Of the 1 billion+ people who rely on computers to get their work done, very few are able to access data, automation & AI to create their own data products.

âš¡ï¸ They might need it to take actions on their social media platforms, develop business opportunities, monitor indicators, better plan and follow their expenses, cash, or automate daily operations.

Our dream is to be able to say "mission accomplished" when everyone on the planet has the power to do this. Until then, stay tuned for an exciting year of Naas updates in 2022.

More templates, more drivers, more features are on the way!!

Donâ€™t forget to spread the #opensource love ğŸ’š!
All the best for this new year everybody âœŒï¸

TITLE: Hey #linkedin spammers âŒ! It's not because I have "coaching" in my bio that "we have a shared passion for fitness"...
TEXT:
Hey #linkedin spammers âŒ! It's not because I have "coaching" in my bio that "we have a shared passion for fitness"...

My thing is coaching individuals and businesses about how to work with data ğŸ˜‡ 


People willing to connect to others on this network need to do their homework. 
Don't you think?

It's like the 10th time I receive connection requests from people in the Fitness industry saying we have a "passion for fitness" 
I always answer them that they completely missed it. 
...and they don't even bother to answer. 

They probably use some kind of automation tool to send batches of requests, but what's the point? 

I believe understanding the context of a profile is key when you want to interact on social media platforms, even more for sales purposes. 

ğŸ‘‰ I also believe NLP and transformers can improve this. 

But we are not there yet. Are we? 
To all my friends in the data space, I would be curious to know how you would handle a problem like this. 

If you have some time, please develop in the comment âœŒï¸


P.S. Yoga and meditation is my kind of fitness by the way ğŸ§˜ğŸ’š

TITLE: ğŸ¥ Video content production is a big pain in the a** ğŸ§…
TEXT:
ğŸ¥ Video content production is a big pain in the a** ğŸ§… 

If you know someone that can help us for naas.ai let us know please ğŸ™

Last year I started posting videos on YouTube but I struggled to be consistent as it takes a lot of time. 

â€¦I wanted those videos to be so clean and professional.  


This year I have 2 options, either:
âœŒï¸I just do it myself and donâ€™t bother so much about the quality 
ğŸ¤™I find a creative buddy that can support me ğŸ˜… 


Below is the todo list Iâ€™ve been trying to follow:
- set the subject and tone
- write a script you can follow
- find the right time to shoot  
- shoot (multiple times) to get good rushs
- watch the rushs 
- make sense of whatâ€™s good to keep
- assemble the good stuff
- re-watch the whole thing 
- edit the final video with intro, outro, background music
- export the video 
- write a description. 
- create a thumbnail that is catch attention
- upload it in YouTube 
- check the automatic transcript 
- add time stamps
- edit transcript to be accurate 
- write a description for YouTube 
- edit and export a 30sec version if you want to post on LinkedIn 
- write a post for LinkedIn 

Do you find it too complex?
Am I missing things here?


If you are a student, freelance, hobbyists video content producer. Please reach out!!

If you are not, please like, comment so it can reach maximum person in your network.

ğŸ‘‰ It can really help our opensource project be more visible ğŸ’š

PS: we plan to produce 1-5 videos per month.

TITLE: â˜ï¸Â My father used to say Â«Â Stop setting up new goals all the time, finish what you started first.Â Â»
TEXT:
â˜ï¸Â My father used to say Â«Â Stop setting up new goals all the time, finish what you started first.Â Â»

And today, during our first meeting of the year at naas.ai, I finally listened to him. 

With the team, we started by reviewing all tasks we did not finished last year. 

(And there was quite a few ğŸ˜)

We dropped the tasks that were not relevant anymore.

And committed to finish the most important first, before setting ANY new goals and objectives.

TITLE: â“ How to learn anything?
TEXT:
â“ How to learn anything?
(a conversation with Thom Ives, Ph.D. inspired this post ğŸ’šğŸ™)

There's an old adage that goes like â€œjack of all trades is a master of noneâ€.

This basically means that he who tries his hand at multiple disciplines will end up being an expert in nothing at all.

However, people like Leonardo Da Vinci, Galileo and most recently Elon Musk dispels this myth as they have pursued in-depth learning across multiple areas to great success.

This is partly due to the talent and skill of these individuals but it's also down to something else known as â€œcross-learningâ€ or â€œtransfer learningâ€.

Basically when you enter into a new field and build knowledge in a new area your new competency inevitably leaks into existing areas of knowledge and can expand and alter your perspective.

This often leads to bringing concepts to a whole new light and coming up with new ideas you would have never thought of otherwise.

By reading a lot, exploring lots of different subject areas, building memory connections, pushing ourselves to the max and hanging out with other motivated and intelligent people, we can perhaps mimic some of the learning success of those great minds ğŸ˜‡.

Don't you think?


#saturdayinspiration #saturdayspecial #saturdayvibe #conversation #education #learning #people #connections #like #success #building #talent #knowledge #greatminds

TITLE: naas.scheduler.add(cron="*/15 * * * *")
TEXT:
naas.scheduler.add(cron="*/15 * * * *") 
â†’ This, is how fast it is to schedule a notebook every 15min in Naas 
ğŸš€

Add this low code formula in a cell, and you will see your notebook copied in the "âš¡ï¸ â†’ Production" folder of your Jupyter Lab instance. 

Each time the notebook runs, it will debit a certain amount of credits (depending on the duration of the execution) on your 100 free credits a month. 

1 credit = 1 minute.

Want to delete? just change it to:
naas.scheduler.delete(), that's it ğŸš€


This simple line of code allows Jupyter Notebook to be the foundation of creating data products. 

We started www.naas.ai with this single feature 2 years ago, inspired by the work of Netflix data team that leverages notebooks in production for key business purposes.

Since then we added more step by step. 

Now we have 6 core features,
around 50 low code drivers,
more than 100 notebooks templates. 

...and a growing open source community ready to make Jupyter notebook the universal layer to access data, automation & AI ğŸ’šğŸŒ

Curious to learn more? 

Check out this 3min video explaining how to use Naas scheduler, create yourself an account on Naas, join our community...we welcome everybody ğŸ™

Thanks a lot for your power with likes and comments.

TITLE: ğŸš€âœ¨ Notebooks + Low-code libraries are opening doors to new horizons, where there is no more bridge to build between tech and non-tech world.
TEXT:
ğŸš€âœ¨ Notebooks + Low-code libraries are opening doors to new horizons, where there is no more bridge to build between tech and non-tech world. 

They will work on the same document to create scalable data products!


The story of coding has always been about writing fewer 0s and 1s. 
More power, less code. 

This is called abstraction.

GUI (graphical user interface) aka no-code tools provide a way to access power without even coding but are limited by the design of the interface.
â†’ You can build things quickly but you are limited by the interface.

Programming languages (HTML, CSS, JS, Python, R) provide access to a limitless world
â†’ You can build anything, but it's easy to fall into the rabbit hole ğŸ©ğŸ°, where you actually end up building nothing. 


âš¡ï¸ This is where low-code comes in. 
Without the need of knowing how to code, you can use "abstracted" code to reduce complexity and increase efficiency.

Excel is a low-code tool, but limited in terms of explainability. 
â†’ How to provide trust on a number that has been built with multiple exports from different tools, manual entries, and unreadable formulas? 
I've been there...it's a real pain!

âš¡ï¸This is where the notebooks come in. 
With their sequential interactive computing cells, they can pair business rules written in natural language in "markdown cells" with low code automation and AI written in "code cells"....and some pure code if needed.

It's like an Excel and a Word document, but with AMAZING superpowers.

naas.ai, PyCaret, Obsei....the number of projects that use low-code + notebooks at the core of their approach is very encouraging.

And you know what's best? 
â†’ Their #opensource nature ğŸ’šğŸŒ

A revolution is on its way. 
Stay tuned âœŒï¸


Big up to Lalit Pagaria, Moez Ali, Nikhil Gupta, and all the low-code teams working hard to abstract access to data, automation & AI.

TITLE: â˜¢ï¸âš¡ï¸ Data scientists NEED to master GitHub for the same reason that software engineers do: collaboration and version control.
TEXT:
â˜¢ï¸âš¡ï¸ Data scientists NEED to master GitHub for the same reason that software engineers do: collaboration and version control. 
They cannot escape it.

No need to try re-invent the wheel. Dropbox or Google drive just don't do the job.

Github is the de-facto standard to safely make changes to projects, and be able to track and roll back changes over time.

Yes, the experience of comparing notebooks is not so great. 
But if you are serious about getting to production, it's a requirement. 

Things to master: 
â†’ Cloning a repository
â†’ Creating a branch 
â†’ Changing branch
â†’ Creating an Issue (= problem)
â†’ Committing your changes 
â†’ Opening a Pull Request (= propose a solution)

and last but not least: 
â†’ Writing efficiently (description, comment, documentation) 

Because COMMUNICATION is always first. 
CODE second.

Do you agree?


P.S. I've been a bit reluctant to use Github when I first started to learn to code, but now, I don't know how to live without it. ğŸ˜… 
Check out how we use it at naas.ai for open source contribution with this step-by-step video.

cc Eddie Jaoude ğŸ˜‰

TITLE: âš¡ï¸ğŸ“ Notion made me realize the power of naas.ai even more today.
TEXT:
âš¡ï¸ğŸ“ Notion made me realize the power of naas.ai even more today. 

In less than 48h hours, we were able to create a fully functional V0 (aka Proof-of-Value) of a data product that automates text summarization from a list of Youtube channels.

On the client-facing side (#frontend) we have:  
- a notion page with the complete product documentation
- a notion database page that already has multiple display capacities (board, gallery, list) + a very powerful search. 

On the #backend side: 
- a couple of Naas notebooks working as modules and scheduled every day to populate Notion.

We would have NEVER been able to create a such valuable product for our client without a tool like Notion to iterate fast.
...AND some magic #lowcode formulas from Naas to abstract the complexity of playing with Notion API. ğŸ˜…âš¡ï¸

Back when we started the Naas project, the concept of an "all-in-one" tool like Notion (all-in-one workspace) was not yet very developed and rather revolutionary. 

Now in retrospect, and after COVID, this tool is getting massive adoption. It's always like that with new technologies. The earlier you get started, the more you get ahead.

â†’ We hope to follow their path with our "all-in-one data platform" approach.
If you did not see our Naas Notion templates yet, check them out with the link in the comment. 


â†’ Anything you want to automate with Notion? 
Let us know. 


More posts about Naas+Notion coming.
Please like and comment to give us power and support ğŸ‘ğŸ’šğŸ’¬

P.S.: Ken Jee we have your request in the backlog to backup Notion to Github ;)
P.S.S: Big up to Hugging Face that has also been crazy useful during this project.

TITLE: ğŸš€ Finally, Naas Open Source Progam is ready!
TEXT:
ğŸš€ Finally, Naas Open Source Progam is ready! 

When we open-sourced Naas a year ago, we did not know anything about how to do it. 

We learned the hard way. 

We failed. 

Fast, and a lot of times. 

But we learned a lot. 

Our key learnings are that in data science, a lot of people need and want to:

(1) showcase their work to be visible on the market
(2) learn how to work on real-life projects or product
(3) get paid to fine-tune the opensource project to the need of clients

This completely reshaped our vision on what we needed to do for the community of naas.ai early contributors.   

So, today, I'm happy to announce that our program is ready and will be starting next week. 

+50 people have already applied (form in comment)

â†’ Objective: gamify the process of contribution and enable our most valuable contributors to make money thanks to Naas!

This will not happen overnight. But all the Naas core team is committed to that vision. 

If you are interested in our approach, apply for the first cohort of contributors that will be called the "Pioneers". 
Any kind of help is welcome. 

We are closing the gates tonight.

Feel free to ask in the comment any questions you may have!
+ LIKE or COMMENT to push this post on your network feed ğŸ™

Naas is an all-in-one data platform that leverages Jupyter Notebooks to create data products.

Our goal is to be the fastest way to generate value from data.

TITLE: ğŸ›‘ âœ‹POC is dead, start creating impact with POV instead (Proof of Value).
TEXT:
ğŸ›‘ âœ‹POC is dead, start creating impact with POV instead (Proof of Value).
Here are 6 practical steps to do it ğŸ‘‡

Proof of Concept (POC) is also known as the pre-sales technical evaluation process. 

POV (Proof of Value)Â is used to identify the value of the product based on customers' use cases. 

It's not the same. 

To do a successful POV, you need to:

(1) Stick to the company's strategy
Your project needs to fit in the company's strategy and provide solutions to impact revenues or expenses.Â 

(2) Define clear objectives
Split â€œtechâ€ objectives (what the product can do) and business-oriented ones.

(3) Bet on the winning combo â€œOperations + Managementâ€
Work with operational business people so they can explain (sell) to the management team. Be there if you can.

(4) Know where to stop
Integrating business teams into a co-creation process is the most critical aspect because you may not know where to stop. Try to narrow your "value perimeter".

(5) Be agile, not fragile
Use a kanban board (Trello, Airtable, Notion..) to share progress and feedback to all parties. Materialize your commitment to the project.

(6) Scale in 3D!
Be sure your POV can expand on 3 dimensions: volume, geography, and business subjects.


...and the BONUS: document your work! 

If you want to do POV for a data project, the best idea in my opinion is to do it with notebooks, they enable both business and tech people to understand what's going on. 

We have done quite a lot of POV with naas.ai, but the best thing is that it can become an actual product without doing anything else with magic low code formulas to send notebooks in production. 

If you have a project in mind, please share it with us, we would be happy to help you set it up.



I hope you learn something from this post.

TITLE: ğŸ˜†ğŸ˜… Humor is a serious business.
TEXT:
ğŸ˜†ğŸ˜… Humor is a serious business. 

How many times did you laugh today? 

A few years back, I became part of the amazing LEAD program at Stanford University Graduate School of Business and attended the best course I ever had. 

The topic: humor in business. 

I just ğŸ’š it.

It's easy to believe that if you take your life or your job seriously, being fun, playful, or joking around makes you less trustworthy in front of other people. 

But what I learned during that course is that successful leaders do serious things without taking themselves too seriously.

In fact, using humor can help anyone perform much better!

Here is the secret sauce to include more humor in business, following the researches from Stanford: 

(1) You need to know your humor style
â†’ Is that:  Standup ğŸ¤? Sweetheart ğŸ˜˜? Sniper ğŸ¯? Magnet ğŸ§²?

(2) Speak your truth 
A lot of funny things are happening during your day. Just try to notice them and share them with people. 
â†’ Example: "Today, without a peepeeÂ teepee, my son would have given me a second shower ğŸ˜Š"

(3) Start small 
You don't become the funniest (and respectable) person in the room overnight, start with moving from transactional to human with tiny funny gestures. 
â†’ Start with a BIG smile anytime you enter a conference call?

(4) Practice safe sets 
You can make fun of your mother, not one of your colleagues. Don't go too far.

(5) Realize humor is a choice
You are the only person responsible for your happiness! 


I would really like to thank Jennifer Aaker and Naomi Bagdonas for such an amazing course. 

Check out the very cool 5min video they made on the topic (link in the comment) 

I am 100% convinced that humor is an under-rated superpower in business.

Are you? 

Feel free to share stories and jokes in the comment. 

I will try to share here more funny stories about what I experience, feel free to join me in this very serious project ğŸ˜Š
Have a beautiful fun day at work. 



Don't forget to share theÂ #opensourceÂ love, always.

TITLE: ğŸ ğŸ’¥ There is a lot of buzzwords in the data space but one is highly under-rated: Citizen Data Scientist (CDS).
TEXT:
ğŸ ğŸ’¥ There is a lot of buzzwords in the data space but one is highly under-rated: Citizen Data Scientist (CDS). 

I summarized below what it means, and why you should care.ğŸ‘‡

There is an exponentialÂ growth in the quantity ofÂ data produced andÂ linear growthÂ ofÂ data insights. 
Basically, we produce more data and we make no use of it. ğŸ—‘

ItÂ isÂ essentialÂ thatÂ organizationsÂ bendÂ theÂ new dataÂ towardsÂ new insights. 
But thatÂ cannotÂ happenÂ unless organizationsÂ expand the number of employees who daily work withÂ data, at scale  âœ…

The trick would be to hire more data scientists, but it's either impossible or out of the question.
(They are expensive,Â difficult to find, hire, and keep on staff.)

ğŸ‘‡
To solve this challenge, tools are evolving. The idea is to do more with fewer resources: "AutoML", "Augmented analytics", "Low-code", "No-code"...

This is where the CDS comes in. 

Gartner says they are peopleÂ who createÂ orÂ generate models but whose primary job function is outside the field of statistics and analytics.Â Â 
In other words, citizen data scientists can perform analytical tasks thatÂ otherwiseÂ requireÂ more expertise. 

TheyÂ canÂ playÂ aÂ complementary roleÂ toÂ "Real" data scientistsÂ andÂ areÂ able to push data models to productionÂ by using:
â†’Â their business experience (subject matter expertise)
â†’ their awareness ofÂ businessÂ priorities.Â 

TADA! 

âœ‹Here I am. Maybe here you are tooâ“

With the role of citizen dataÂ scientists,Â organizationsÂ are able to bridgeÂ the gap betweenÂ business analytics usersÂ and advanced analytics data scientists are able to do.

ğŸ‘‰ This sweet spot is where we position naas.ai in the data ecosystem. 

Although this role has notÂ yetÂ gained a lot ofÂ popularity, when you look atÂ "data specialist"Â positionsÂ onÂ job research, websites, it's clear thatÂ citizenÂ data scienceÂ is becoming oneÂ of theÂ most criticalÂ rolesÂ inÂ data teams.


I hope you learn something from this post.

TITLE: I'm BACK ğŸ˜Š, feeling more motivated than ever to change the game in the data space!
TEXT:
I'm BACK ğŸ˜Š, feeling more motivated than ever to change the game in the data space! 
...and I have 3 BIG announcements to make today ğŸ‘‡ğŸš¨

(1) Becoming a dad and working with an amazing team gives you superpowers. ğŸ’š 
I was able to enjoy my time off for the past 15 days and completely disconnect. 

(2) It's been exactly 1 year and 5 days since we have launched www.naas.ai on Product Hunt ğŸ‚

(3) We have pushed a major update to the naas.ai manager. ğŸš€

This evolution is our humble contribution to solving one of the most critical pain points in any data project.

We have been working on it since we launched the Naas cloud version in Amazon Web Services (AWS) in January 2020. 

Taking time to experiment and learn from our first users has been our biggest asset.

Can you guess what it is?

= MEASURING VALUE.

To do that, you need to know what are the costs (human + machine) and the benefits. 

Benefits and human costs are quite easy to do, but when it comes to machines, it's almost impossible to follow costs at the micro/task level.

âš¡ï¸âš¡ï¸âš¡ï¸ We made it possible in Naas version 2, where you can now have complete visibility on:

â†’ JOBS: use of Naas features like scheduling, asset sharing, notifications...
â†’ EVENTS: execution of jobs
â†’ USAGE: in credits and in dollar value

Find attached an example for the free plan, where we offer the equivalent of 5$ of free credits per month!

âœ… If you are already a Naas user, make sure you restart your server to update your Naas version and enjoy this new level of transparency.

ğŸŸ  If you are not already a Naas user, you can create your account for free with the link below âš¡ï¸âš¡ï¸âš¡ï¸

TITLE: ğŸª£ Do you use Amazon Web Services (AWS) S3? What is your use case?
TEXT:
ğŸª£ Do you use Amazon Web Services (AWS) S3? What is your use case?
Check out this template to quickly access S3 files! ğŸ‘‡

Amazon S3 for Amazon Simple Storage Service is a service by Amazon Web Services that provides object storage through a web service interface. 

Amazon S3 uses the same scalable storage infrastructure that Amazon uses to run its global e-commerce network! 
...no wonder why it's very powerful!

ğŸ’ª It's built to store, protect and retrieve data from â€œbucketsâ€ at any time from anywhere on any device. 

Using Amazon S3Â facilitates highly scalable, secured, and low-latency data storage from the cloud. 

ğŸ’° At naas.ai, we have seen use cases where S3 is used as an input to run a Sales prediction model that automatically sends an Email + attaches a detailed Excel file, every Monday at 9 AM to a Head of Sales.

(with the help of naas scheduler + asset + notification featuresğŸ˜Š)

The truth is, if you are not familiar with using S3, it can take time to set up, access files from a notebook, and share them securely.

âœ… If you are looking for a shortcut, check out this very useful notebook ğŸ‘‡

This notebook uses the boto3 python library + generate a presigned URL so you can provide and grant temporary access to a specific S3 object.


I hope you find it useful.ğŸ™ğŸ™

Thanks for your support and feel free to share your experience with S3s in the comment section, or ask questions! ğŸ’¬ğŸ‘

TITLE: ğŸŒ¡ğŸŒ "It's pretty much a given that that the 2Â°C will occur... the question is whether it's going to be much more than that..."
TEXT:
ğŸŒ¡ğŸŒ "It's pretty much a given that that the 2Â°C will occur... the question is whether it's going to be much more than that..."

Today, I rewatched a 12 min crystal clear video of Elon Musk breaking down climate change for students at The Sorbonne in Paris (France's Harvard). 

It was right before the historic COP21 climate change conference in which 192 nations signed the Paris Agreement in 2015 to reduce carbon emissions below 2Â°C, and preferably under 1.5Â°C.  

Since then : 

1ï¸âƒ£Â Over 1 000 big companies pledged major emissions reductions

2ï¸âƒ£Â Major cities are improving urban life while building climate resilience

3ï¸âƒ£ Financial Institutions recognize that funding fossil fuels is a bad investment (yet the sector is still massively subsidies)

4ï¸âƒ£Â Technological advances make renewable energy more attainable

5ï¸âƒ£Â Expanding social movements reflect the publicâ€™s growing demand for climate action

6ï¸âƒ£ Country-level action is starting to accelerate

YET one thing is still missing at the global level following Musk's thesis.
ğŸ‘‡ 

ğŸ’°A global CARBON TAX. 

This is the takeaway of the Musk video:

"Whenever you have the opportunity to talk to your politicians, ask them to enact a carbon tax. 

We have to fix the unpriced externality. 

Talk to your friends about it and fight the propaganda from the carbon industry."

ğŸ™ I hope this topic will be on the table of COP26 in Glasgow.

Today is day 31 of my #66daysofdata and I worked on the NASA dataset that follows the global temperature.

Thanks for your support and feel free to share your views in the comment section ğŸ’¬ğŸ‘

P.S. Check out Musk's video in the comment.

TITLE: Do you use Google Sheets in your data jobs?
TEXT:
Do you use Google Sheets in your data jobs? 
Check out this notebook template to speed up your time to insight! ğŸ‘‡

Google Sheets is the most popular alternative to Excel because of its excellent collaboration abilities. 

Multiple people can be working on the same spreadsheet at the same time, without any lagging or confusion. 

But accessing Google Sheet when you want to play with data in Python (in Jupyter notebooks or other data platforms) can be painful, long, and tedious.

ğŸ‘‰ With naas_drivers, get straight to the point and access or send data from Gsheets in 1 minute!

Here are the very simple steps: 

1ï¸âƒ£ Import the library
import naas_drivers

2ï¸âƒ£ Share your spreadsheet with the Naas service account: 
naas-share@naas-gsheets.iam.gserviceaccount.com

3ï¸âƒ£ Access data
df = naas_drivers.gsheet.connect(spreadsheet_id).get(sheet_name)
df

4ï¸âƒ£ Send data
df = naas_drivers.gsheet.connect(spreadsheet_id).send(sheet_name, data)
df

The problem I see with Google library in Python is that it does not come with those features embedded.

You need to configure Google admin console + code and it's time-consuming.

I hope you find the Naas low code approach useful.

 Good or bad thing?

Since we launched naas.ai we have identified that companies struggle toÂ follow costs and ROI of data jobs (humansÂ + machines)

This is preventing them from truly entering into a "Data monetization" phase.

The data stays in the hands of some happy few and never reaches a land of new opportunities. 

Naas is trying to fix this with:
âš¡ï¸business-ready templates to decrease the cost of development
âš¡ï¸a credit-based system to monitor the cost of running modelsÂ in production

We have seen applications in : 
ğŸ’° Growth Marketing
ğŸ’° Sales
ğŸ’° Product development
ğŸ’° Financial controlling

...and it's a bit overwhelming because it can apply to a lot of situations.

I am almost halfway in my #66daysofdata (this is day 29) and I'm thinking of creating content on each of these business domains.

TITLE: âš¡ï¸ğŸ˜Š Low-code has the power to dramatically improve the lives of data professionals looking to rapidly build production tooling.
TEXT:
âš¡ï¸ğŸ˜Š Low-code has the power to dramatically improve the lives of data professionals looking to rapidly build production tooling. 

Today during the naas.ai Open Source Office Hours, we talked about it and started a real use case using Plotly. 

The idea is to create a "one line of code" production-ready chart library on top of Plotly to get consistent design.

Here is the takeaway: 

â†’ Create your first notebooks following the Naas framework (input/model/output)

â†’ Once your notebook work fine, think about how to abstract the complexity of the chart configuration 

â†’ Keep only what you need and start creating a function passing the parameters you want to keep

â†’ Once your function is ready, integrate it into the naas driver repository

â†’ Make sure it works by testing it locally

â†’ Push your naas driver to Github, wait for the CI to deploy it in Pypi, and then validate it works ğŸ¤™

âš¡ï¸You can now create charts in one line and focus on what matters: the adoption of your end-users! âš¡ï¸

Less code, more business ğŸ˜Š

I hope you find this useful!

TITLE: ğŸ”´ğŸ“Š Charts and data storytelling are critical parts of the #datascience job.
TEXT:
ğŸ”´ğŸ“Š Charts and data storytelling are critical parts of the #datascience job. 
Yet this area is often overlooked. Why?

My opinion is that it's because it should come FIRST, not LAST in the process.

What we usually try to do: 
â†’ access data
â†’ understand it
â†’ process it
â†’ extract value from it
â†’ visualize it (charts)
â†’ communicate it (data storytelling)

But, one guy once said: "You've got toÂ start with the customerÂ experience andÂ work backwardÂ to the technology"
(Steve Jobs)

So if you transpose it to data, maybe we should "do things differently"
â†’ communicate with the audience on what needs to be seen 
â†’ visualize it in charts

and then only
â†’ access data
â†’ understand it
â†’ process it
â†’ extract value from it to fill the charts.

âš¡ï¸ We are going to talk about it during naas.ai open source office hours tomorrow at 5PM Paris time.

The idea is to create low-code drivers on top of Plotly with Naas open source contributors to enable usage of pre-built charts with improved design...with limited technical configuration.

ğŸ’š We believe it will bring a seamless experience for the creator and for the audience.

Do you find this interesting?
If yes, feel free to join us tomorrow ğŸ‘‡

Thanks for your support and happy to share ideas in the comment section ğŸ’¬ğŸ‘

TITLE: ğŸ”´ğŸ’°What's the point of machine learning projects if they are not profitable?
TEXT:
ğŸ”´ğŸ’°What's the point of machine learning projects if they are not profitable?

Today, letâ€™s talk about estimating the return on investment (ROI) in data science and machine learning projects.

This is day 26 of my #66daysofdata

In 2006, Netflix announced the Netflix Prize, a $1 million-worth data science tournament.

The winning team had to provide a machine learning model that would increase their movie-recommendation system accuracy by 10%.Â 

â†’ 3 years later, the prize was paid... But Netflix didnâ€™t use the algorithm.Â 

ğŸ¤¨Why?Â 

They considered that the gains were too low compared to the effort.

ğŸ‘‰ Estimating ROI in data science is HARD.

I believe these types of projects have a lot more uncertainty than traditional software engineering.

So many of them fail to deliver value or go over budget.
And thatâ€™s even worse with data science.

Maybe it's because data science projects are to be considered R&D: research and development.

It's usually easy to estimate the D (specification of what the system should do)
But this R is a real pain!Â 

Research means you have to explore and iterate.

If this part is validated, maybe deploying it to production is too expensive and the gains donâ€™t justify it, just like the case with Netflix.

If it is not if you realize that the implementation isnâ€™t feasible at all. We just canâ€™t do it. END.

My 2 cents on this:
â†’ If you want to estimate the ROI of your data science project, you should do it after a data scientist does some research.

The rest is pretty basic. The formula for ROI is simple.

(Gains - Cost of investment) / Cost of investment

...But you need to calculate what goes into these two variables.

And this is the hardest part.

ğŸ‘‡
Do you agree? 

If you want me to deep dive into this topic in the coming posts, please like and comment. 

Coming from a finance background, I feel like it's something missing in the data science game today. 

Thanks for your support ğŸ‘ğŸ’¬

TITLE: ğŸ˜¶â€ğŸŒ«ï¸ Today I've been diagnosed with a light version of Vitiligo, a long-term condition where pale white patches develop on the skin.
TEXT:
ğŸ˜¶â€ğŸŒ«ï¸ Today I've been diagnosed with a light version of Vitiligo, a long-term condition where pale white patches develop on the skin.

In this 25th post of #66daysofdata, I felt I had to write about itğŸ‘‡

If you don't know what Vitiligo is, here is the data I found:

â†’ Vitiligo is an autoimmune disorder and not merely a â€œcosmeticâ€ problem.

â†’ Vitiligo affects the immune system which then affects the skin, resulting in white patches.

â†’ 70 million people across the world have vitiligo.

â†’ There are no boundaries of race, ethnicity, or gender.

â†’ Anyone - children and adults representing all ethnicities - can get vitiligo at any time.

â†’ 20-35% of patients are children.

â†’ Nearly 1% of the population is affected.

â†’ Vitiligo is NOT contagious.

â†’ Vitiligo is difficult to hide. 

â†’ This disease is misunderstood and the isolation people with vitiligo feel can be crippling.

â†’ Psychologically devastating, many patients feel isolated and devastated by its impact on their relationships and personal and professional lives.

â†’ There is no known cure.

â†’ There is very little research funding for vitiligo to better understand the disease and develop new treatments.

â†’ Many of the currently available treatments are not covered by insurance.

â†’ Various treatments, including topical creams and light therapy, can help some patients.

â†’ More treatments and research are needed.

â˜€ï¸ When I started realizing this a few months ago, I sometimes used make-up when I was going on camera.

I did not know what it was, but I felt a bit stressed out about showing my face to the camera.

ğŸ™ Now that I know what it is, and that a lot of people are suffering from this.

I feel like I don't have to hide it with anything, and keep pushing YouTube videos even more! 

ğŸ’š Because we must all live with our differences, and embrace them. 

Cheers  ğŸ¤™
#disorder #skin #autoimmunedisease #vitiligo #data #support #diversity #diversityandinclusion #diversitymatters

TITLE: ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ³ âœ¨ What are the 12 steps of AI?
TEXT:
ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ³ âœ¨ What are the 12 steps of AI? 

Today is day 24 of my #66daysofdata, and I rewatched some videos from Cassie Kozyrkov. 

I just love the simplicity of her explanations. She uses the analogy of the kitchen to explain how to "cook" impactful AI projects.

Here are my takeaway notes: 

ğŸ• Step 0-1: Ask the right questionsÂ 
â†’ Step business objectives, decide the required qualityÂ 

ğŸ•Step 2-4: Get the right data
â†’ Source, manage, prepare the right ingredients

ğŸ•Step 5-7: Use algorithms to make recipes from patterns in the data
â†’ Tinker the appliances, get creative, make recipe

ğŸ•Step 8-9: Check that the recipes work on new data
â†’ Taste it! Iterate if result isnâ€™t tasty enough

ğŸ•Step 10: Build a production-ready system
â†’ Arrange kitchen so you can serve this recipe all day

ğŸ•Step 11: Make sure that launching is a good idea
â†’ Ensure customers like it before adding to menuÂ 

ğŸ•Step 12: Keep your production system reliable over time
â†’ Keep your kitchen process reliable over time


I hope you find this useful!

If you have not seen her video series "Making Friends with Machine Learning", invest that time. It's totally worth it.

TITLE: ğŸ› ğŸ“Š How to use bubble charts?
TEXT:
ğŸ› ğŸ“Š How to use bubble charts? 

This is my #66daysofdata day 23. 

A bubble chart isÂ a data visualization that displays multiple circles (bubbles) in a two-dimensional plot. 
It is a generalization of the scatter plot, replacing the dots with bubbles.

ğŸŸ  Bubble charts can be complicated to read because they are used to determineÂ if 3 or more numerical values share some kind of pattern. 

â†’ The first 2 are a pair of numerical values (A, B) positioning the bubble in a coordinate system: horizontally according to the value of variable A and vertically according to variable B. 

â†’ The third numerical value (C) is represented by theÂ area of the bubble. 

You can even incorporate more values (D: numerical or categorical) using different colors in different bubbles.

ğŸ’¬The story is narrated from the shape that these data points generate as well as from the differences in the relative sizes of the bubbles. 

Important as well â†’ there must be appropriate legends represented by the colors.

ğŸ‘‡
In this example, you can see 
A = Life Expectancy 
B = GDP per Capita
C = Population 
and the colors represent the continent. 

It seems very clear GDP is correlated with life expectancy, and that some actions need to be taken on the African continent in green.

âš¡ï¸You can play with this bubble chart by just running the Naas template that I pushed today (link in comment)âš¡ï¸

I hope you find this useful!

TITLE: We donâ€™t KISS enough ğŸ¤—ğŸ’‹ Keep it simple and stupid
TEXT:
We donâ€™t KISS enough ğŸ¤—ğŸ’‹ Keep it simple and stupid 

ğŸ‘‡
Keep it simple and stupid (KISS) is a design principle saying that designs + systems should be as simple as possible. 

Wherever possible, complexity should be avoided. 

The idea is simple: simplicity guarantees the greatest levels of user adoption.

KISS is used in a variety of disciplines: interface design, product design, and software development, but I feel that in data science, itâ€™s missing sometimes.

The term was first used in the US Navy to describe systems that can be repaired by a man in a combat situation with only some basic mechanicâ€™s training and simple tools.

âš¡ï¸This is the kind of mindset we should all target while building data pipelines/engines. 

Make sure to keep it simple so that even a non-tech people can understand and fix it.

Itâ€™s about:
- documenting 
- packaging complex code into functions and libraries 
- writing errors messages that can be understood by anyone.

This is why we are building low code python formulas we call the Â«Â naas driversÂ Â» and implement them into naas.ai  notebooks templates. 

Yesterday, we started talking about it during our live session. 

Iâ€™m planning to deep dive about it in the coming post and hope you will find it interesting. ğŸ™

TITLE: ğŸ“ŠğŸ•¯ Let's light a candle today, I created a template for THE most famous chart in trading: the Candlestick!
TEXT:
ğŸ“ŠğŸ•¯ Let's light a candle today, I created a template for THE most famous chart in trading: the Candlestick!
Do you know how it works? ğŸ‘‡

Candlestick charts are used byÂ traders to determine possible price movement based on past patterns. 

The concept has been developed in the 18th century byÂ Munehisa Homma, aÂ JapaneseÂ rice trader.

Candlesticks are useful when trading as they show four price points (open, close, high, and low) throughout the period of time the trader specifies. 

â†’ The area between the open and the close is called theÂ real body, 
â†’ Price excursions above and below the real body areÂ shadowsÂ (also calledÂ wicks). 
â†’ Wicks illustrates the highest and lowest traded prices of an asset during the time interval represented. 
â†’ The price range is the distance between the top of the upper shadow and the bottom 

ğŸ‘ The cool stuff with this version is the "Rangeslider" 
âœ… It enables you to quickly deep dive on a certain timeframe to analyze the price range. 

In this example, you can see a 1-year timeframe of the Tesla Stock price and in 3 seconds, a deep dive into the last trading days.
You have both the trend + the details.

I hope you find this useful!

TITLE: ğŸ“ŠğŸ˜“ Today I got into a fight with Plotly heatmap. ğŸ¥Š
TEXT:
ğŸ“ŠğŸ˜“ Today I got into a fight with Plotly heatmap. ğŸ¥Š

I spent around 1 hour creating the chart I wanted. Am I the only one struggling?

The idea was simple: create a Sales Performance heatmap like a lot of Top Executives like to have (ğŸ˜‰ Alexis Monville)

It's a nice chart to be able to understand the sales matrix. 

â†’ You have business lines or units. 
â†’ You have products available in each units. 
â†’ You want to understand if you are above (green) or below (red) your sales target 
â†’ If you see squares in red, you want to take action. 

Simple right?

Not so fast ğŸ˜‰
First, you need to create a data frame that adapts to heatmap data model. 
Then, you need to take the Plotly heatmap example in the documentation and :
â†’ add a Title 
â†’ hide the legend 
â†’ understand how the color scales work (probably the most tricky part)
â†’ investigate how to put spaces between the squares
â†’ delete the default background to make it white. 
â†’ custom the tooltip

...it's not that easy. 
âš¡ï¸ But don't worry, I have just added my open source contribution (chart on the right) to naas.ai awesome-notebooks repository. 

Next time you want to do a heatmap â†’ just start with the Naas templates (link in the comment)

ğŸ™ Hope you find this valuable.

TITLE: ğŸ“ŠğŸ¤“ Plotly library is overwhelming. You can do a lot, but if you just want to go fast and simple. It's hard.
TEXT:

Don't you think?ğŸ‘‡

Today is day 17 of myÂ #66daysofdata, I explored the Plotly library and tried to create a common design framework for my charts. 

The Plotly Python library is awesome. 
It's anÂ interactive, open-source plotting libraryÂ that supports over 40 unique chart types covering a wide range of statistical, financial, geographic, scientific use cases (even 3D Rodney ğŸ˜‰) 

The problem is that the examples in the documentation are not following some key design principles.

TITLE: âš¡ï¸ğŸ“Š What makes a good chart? 10 things I've learned.
TEXT:
âš¡ï¸ğŸ“Š What makes a good chart? 10 things I've learned. 

Do you agree?ğŸ‘‡

Today is day 16 of my #66daysofdata, and I wanted to come back to design and data visualization. 

Here are the 10 things I always try to follow. 

(1) One graph per business need
Your audience needs to understand the topic in 3 sec.

(2)  Choose the right chart for the right need. 
ğŸ™ Don't use Pie charts for more than 3 values, it's easily replaceable by a horizontal bar chart. 

I always try to categorize by the kind of need
â†’ Evolution? line chart, vertical bar chart, timeline
â†’ Comparaison? horizontal bar chart, scorecard, leaderboard, bullet chart, heatmap
â†’ Breakdown? waterfall chart, stacked barchart
â†’ Mapping? mapchart or heatmap

(3) 3D is for video games not for charts.

(4) Prefer the white background.

(5) Leveraged the natural eye movement of left-to-right and top-to-bottom.

(6) Removed redundant elements such as grids or axes.

(7) Use light colors and scales, nice does not mean efficient.

(8) Play on the size, proximity, typography.

(9) Use contextual elements to drive focus.

(10) Use straight-to-the-point titles, subtitles, and descriptions.


The problem I see with dataviz library in Python is that they don't come with those features embedded. 

You need to code and it's time-consuming. 

I will soon release a complete set of charts in Plotly that follows those principles. 

Stay tuned ğŸ¤˜ Share the open source loveğŸ’š

I hope you find this useful.

TITLE: ğŸŒğŸ’¬ Interested in Open Source + NLP but don't know where to start?
TEXT:
ğŸŒğŸ’¬ Interested in Open Source + NLP but don't know where to start?

If you missed our LinkedIn live event yesterday, we talked about it. 

Don't worry, here is the memo ğŸ‘‡


âš¡ï¸ Eddie Jaoude came to say Hi (he is one of the top Open Source contributors on GitHub, so thanks for your support ğŸ™) 

âš¡ï¸ Gagan Bhatia came to the stage and shared his contribution experience on Naas Hugging Face driver and other open source projects.

âš¡ï¸ The success of your journey (but also outside of open source) is simple: "Communication First, Code Second"

âš¡ï¸You don't have to contribute only code
It can be documentation, answering questions...anything.

âš¡ï¸Issues = Problem
Start with the "Good First Issue" tag on any kind of repo, they are made for new contributors.

âš¡ï¸Pull Request = Solution
Even if it's not perfect just push something and communicate about it. Only the maintainer will decide when it's ready to merge to the master branch anyway. 

âš¡ï¸Find a subject that is interesting for you! 
If you don't know, come and talk to Open Source project maintainers so they can tell you how best you can help.

âš¡ï¸Understand the GitHub contribution workflow.  
A lot of people who are not familiar don't contribute because they are not familiar with Git. 

âš¡ï¸ Push a little bit every day. 
Yesterday, we started with Gagan Bhatia a contribution live that was mixing 2 templates: one to extract a transcript, the other to summarize text, and today I finished it + recorded the ğŸ”´ Live contribution for you! ğŸŒ

It's pretty basic, yet a good start for understanding how to use NLP.

Cheers.

No fear. No ego. Just be passionate ğŸ’š ...and spread the open source love.

TITLE: ğŸŒ The principles behind open source are changing our world.
TEXT:
ğŸŒ The principles behind open source are changing our world.

The digital-first world we live in today has been driven by the free exchange of ideas, collaboration, and meritocracy.

These principles have been so effective precisely because they mirror the way we have solved problems for millennia, but the internet gave these principles a new name: open source.

In this Live series called "Open Source Office Hours", we are going to deep dive into this MASSIVE subject.

If you are a data analyst, data engineer, data scientist, or just a data geekâ€¦wanting to get started with open source. I can also provide live mentoring and coaching.

âš¡ï¸naas.ai is an all-in-one open source data platform, based on Jupyter Notebooks (the most popular Open Source tool in data science).

Our mission is to enable access to data, automation and AI for anyone thanks to notebooks templates and low-code formulas.

We are building Naas in public, sharing everything bit of information we can.

TITLE: ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€ğŸ« âœ¨ Data is just noise, it's chaos.
TEXT:
ğŸ‘¨ğŸ»â€ğŸ« âœ¨ Data is just noise, it's chaos.
Have you ever heard about the DIKW pyramid?

If not, you have to read this.


ğŸ‘‰Understanding the big picture first will set the stage for your success in your data journey.

So what does this pyramid means?

The DIKW Pyramid representsÂ the relationships between Data, Information, Knowledge, and Wisdom.

âœ¨ DataÂ is just a set of signals or symbols. Nothing more than noise.

âœ¨ When you apply systems to organize data, it starts being useful and becomes Information.

âœ¨ Knowledge allows us to detect patterns in the Information. Itâ€™s the foundation that will let us build predictive models and generate real insights.

âœ¨ Wisdom is all about the future: it relies on Knowledge but it can help to shape your â€œgut feelingâ€ and intuition, giving you an exponential competitive advantage.

The Hierarchy, much like Maslowâ€™s Hierarchy, illustrates thatÂ there is a large and necessary â€œfoundationâ€ to the pyramid.

ğŸ™ We must aspire to move to the top of the pyramid to reach Wisdom.

Keeping this framework in mind has helped me organize my thoughts and deliver data projects for the past 5 years.

What you need to do, is not go blindly into the data.

Visualize what wisdom will be like.
= What will make your project a success in the eyes of everyone?

If you find this interesting, please like and comment ğŸ˜‰ğŸ‘ ğŸ’¬

BONUS ğŸ‘‡
The origin of this mental framework is coming from a poet: T.S.Eliot.

In 1934 Eliot wrote:
""
Where is the Life we have lost in living?
Where is the wisdom we have lost in Knowledge?
Where is the knowledge we have lost in Information?
""

Yes! It's not even coming from a data scientist ğŸ˜…

TITLE: ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ³ğŸ¤® Why do businesses fail at machine learning?
TEXT:
ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ³ğŸ¤® Why do businesses fail at machine learning?

Today I re-watched the video of Cassie Kozyrkov on this topic and used 2 naas.ai templates to: 

â†’ Extract the transcript from the YouTube video
â†’ Run Hugging Face naas driver and perform NLP text summarization task on the transcript, using T5-small model.

The results are pretty cool. 
This is what came out.ğŸ‘‡

"""

The research machine learning and applied side the decision intelligence side are as different from one another as building microwave ovens and innovating in recipes in the kitchen at scale.

It's almost like no one thought about the era where we would have warehouses upon warehouses of microwaves waiting ready to go.

The entire strategy here is hope. You hope that someone will spend their whole lives learning every little detail about how to make a better microwave and at some point we'll transcend and become a great chef.

"""

Indeed, Cassie is using this "chef allegory" to explain why businesses fail at machine learning. 

ğŸ’¬ If I would have summarized it myself, I would have said that it's because companies emphasis too much on hiring top-notch researchers (that understand the deep complexity of the ML algorithms) and not enough on hiring people that can use the ML algorithm to fix business problems.

This insight from Cassie, Chief Decision Scientist at Google, is HUGE. 

âš¡ï¸It's time to use ML to fix business problems, we have enough ML algorithms ready to use and easy to integrate into notebooks, to deliver value for businesses. 

â†’ I will push the notebook I built on Github soon.

â€¦but it took me literally 3min to build it, so I also challenge you to build it yourself ğŸ˜‰ (links in comment)

TITLE: ğŸ”´ğŸ‘” NO! You don't need to become a data scientist to start using Python to consolidate your files instead of Excel!
TEXT:
ğŸ”´ğŸ‘” NO! You don't need to become a data scientist to start using Python to consolidate your files instead of Excel!
#66daysofdata Day 7

Before switching to data, I worked in Finance and did a lot of Excel. 
...I spent HOURS of my life copy-pasting tables under each other...and I know there is still plenty of people doing it. 

Excel is still, to date, the best friend of my fellow finance people for consolidation. 

But it's NOT necessarily the best tool for financial consolidation. 

ğŸ Instead, you should use a simple "For" Loop in Python. 

A "For" Loop is usedÂ to repeat a specific block of code a known number of times, also called an iteration.

Here is how it goes: 

## Input 
â†’ Import the necessary libraries: os and pandas 

## Model 
Use a for loop to 
â†’ List all the files in the current directory with os.listdir().
â†’ Filter files with the .endswith(â€˜.xlsxâ€™) method.
â†’ Make sure the files will be stored into a list called my_list and then combined with pd.concat()
Then
â†’ Return a dataframe and name it df_concat. 

## Output
â†’ Export your dataframe to an Excel file.

ğŸ’š The beauty of this is that you can reuse it for everything.


I just pushed a Notebook template on naas.ai GitHub repository on this topic.
ğŸ‘‰ Click the link below, then on the "Open in Naas" button, and try it out LIVE.

TITLE: âœ¨ ğŸ´â€â˜ ï¸ What is GitHub?...and why every data scientist must master how to use it.
TEXT:
âœ¨ ğŸ´â€â˜ ï¸ What is GitHub?...and why every data scientist must master how to use it.

Unfortunately, it's often not the case.


GithubÂ is one of the most well-known and widely used platforms forÂ "version control".

Version control, also known as source control, is theÂ practice of tracking and managing changes on code.

Files, where the code is written, are stored in a central remote location known as a repository. It's basically a folder. 

ğŸª„ But the magic is that each time you make a change on this folder and push it to Github, a new version of this folder will be stored and recorded forever. It's called a commit. 

It means that you can roll back whenever you want.

â“ But what if you are working as a team?

ğŸ‘‰ For that, you need to understand the concept of branching, a temporary copy of the master folder, where you can make changes there first without fear of breaking anything.

But that's not all! 

The real magic happens when everyone masters this workflow:

(1) An Issue is raised on the repository â†’ Issue = The Problem

(2) This Issue is linked to a Project Roadmap â†’ Github provides a Kanban board to do that: Github Project

(3) A member of the team is assigned to this issue and starts working on it on a branch.

(4) When the Issue has been completed â†’ a commit to the branch and a Pull Request can be sent for review = The Solution 

(5) If the review is successful, the reviewer can merge the Pull Request to the "master" branch 

(6) Bonus: a CI (continuous integration) makes some additional controls to make sure nothing will break. 

I believe this workflow can DRAMATICALLY improve data teams' efficiency and productivity. 


ğŸ’¬ What do you think? Did I miss something?


We are using it for the naas.ai project, our contributors use it, it's very efficient and I really encourage everyone to try it for their project. 

ğŸ“º Check out this step-by-step tutorial about it.

P.S. This post is part of myÂ #66daysofdata, this is day 4!Â 
P.S.S. In the first comment, the link to our awesome-notebooks repository.

TITLE: ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’» Do you need to learn how to code to become a data scientist?
TEXT:
ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’»ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ’» Do you need to learn how to code to become a data scientist?

Yes? No? Letâ€™s debate.


Before I learned how to code I used this program called Excel.Â 

You may have already heard about it. ğŸ˜…

What you donâ€™t realize, is that when you are writing formulas in Excel,Â you are actually already coding...

â€¦â€œlow codingâ€ to be more accurate.

You are not really coding, but you are using a certain level of abstraction (the formulas) to write language that your machine will understand.Â 

ğŸ”´ When I started working in Treasury, I had to produce tons of reports every month in Excel.

I quickly realized that analyzing data via this point-and-click interface and low code formulas was not so efficient.Â 

ğŸ It really requires manual time in which I have to physically use the mouse to click the program, import the data, set up the spreadsheet, arrange formulas together + wait minutes (or hours) for my computer to deliver the output.Â 

â†’ It was quite tedious but most of all not reproducible nor auditable.Â 

VSÂ 

âœ… When I learned how to code in Python and Jupyter notebooks, I realized that I could do a lot more, in less time.Â 

Coding gives you the power to create and automate anything you wantâ€¦without using your mouse ğŸª¤

â†’ And everybody can run this code, and reproduce your work.


Iâ€™m still a big fan of Excel but YES I would recommend everybody to learn how to code.

It might be overwhelming at first but you can start small.Â 

Learn about the basics: HTML, CSS, JS, then Python or R for data science.Â 
It feels liberating.Â 

ğŸ‘‰ Check out this Notebook template I made to create an end-to-end website in 5min.

Just open the link in the first comment, click on the â€œOpen in Naasâ€ button, and play the cells of the notebook
ğŸ‘‡

Input part :Â 
â†’ Download the HTML file behind example .com website in PythonÂ 

Modeling part:Â 
â†’ Click right to open + edit the file downloadedÂ 
â†’ Display the Stanford HTML cheat sheet to learn about HTML
â†’ Manually change the text to make it your own
â†’ Use Google search to go further in the customization (I recommend using Stackoverflow + W3Schools)

Output part:Â 
â†’ Use Naas asset formula to generate a shareable URL.Â 


ğŸª„ Et voila, you have a website running for free.Â 


You can also check out the video replay of our Open Source Office Hours (it starts at min 23:54) where I explain how simple it is in more detail ğŸ¤ª

If you watch it all you will benefit from the wise advice of our special guests:Â Denis RothmanÂ andÂ Thom Ives, Ph.D.

P.S. This post is part of myÂ #66daysofdata, this is day 3!Â

TITLE: ğŸš€ğŸ¥‡ Why are Jupyter Notebooks so popular in the data space?Â
TEXT:
ğŸš€ğŸ¥‡ Why are Jupyter Notebooks so popular in the data space?Â 


Jupyter notebook is basically a document where you can write text and run code within a web browser.Â 

Itâ€™sÂ an indirect acronym of three languages â€” Julia, Python, and R.

It has originally been build to documenting research and scientific papers.

But now itâ€™s powering a lot of teams and business applications.Â 

âœï¸ The text is written in Markdown.
âš™ï¸ The code can be written in different languages (40+ programming languages supported)

What Makes Jupyter Notebook the "De Facto Choice" is without a doubt its #opensource and interactive computing nature. ğŸ’š

â†’ Project Jupyter is maintained by an amazing team of contributors from different industries and has become the universal layer to do data science.

A lot of Jupyter notebook based services are now flourishing in the market:
- Deepnote focuses on data teams and collaboration 
- Google Colab provides free GPU and sync with your google drive
...
...the list of Jupyter powered solutions is very long! ğŸ¤ª

naas.ai is one of them and contrary to others, we want to keep intact the original project and stay open source. 

ğŸª„ We simply added some magic features around it to enable anyone to build end-to-end products. 

Coming from Excel, I was sometimes not able to explain to my boss how I got the result I was presenting to him. Too many data sources, copy/paste of cells, manual plugsâ€¦Â 

With Jupyter Notebooks, those frictions are over. 

It is the best way of crafting a story with data and bring full transparency on how it has been written.


Do you agree?


P.S. This post is part of my #66daysofday, this is day 2! Today finished the Youtube playlist of Data Professor, created my plan for the challenge, and I wanted to come back on this essential tool in the data science arsenal.Â 

Thanks for your support ğŸ™

TITLE: Hey! ğŸ‘‹ My name is JÃ©rÃ©my Ravenel and today I start my #66daysofdata challenge. This is day 1.
TEXT:
Hey! ğŸ‘‹ My name is JÃ©rÃ©my Ravenel and today I start my #66daysofdata challenge. This is day 1.

What does this hashtag even mean?

"66 days of data" is an initiative that Ken Jee started in 2020.

The big idea is that for 66 days you spend at least 5 minutes each day learning about data science.

ğŸ¯ The objective of this challenge is to share what you learned each day to create a habit of learning and sharing your work.Â  

You can do it on your platform of choice:Â 
Linkedin, Twitter, Facebook, or on the discord community that's been created that has 6k+ members!!!

âœ… There are 2 main benefits :Â 

(1) You are creating a habit around learning every dayÂ 
â†’ Data is this field where you are never going to be done learning, so it's quite an important aspect.Â 

(2) It is creating accountability
â†’ Putting your work out gives your a little extra social pressure to keep you going. 


ğŸ’š What I liked about this 66 days challenge is the community aspect.Â 

But I didn't feel legitimate to do it until I listened to Ken Jee's video saying that "Project-based" learning was for him the most effective way of learning.Â  

And could not agree more. This is how I roll ğŸ˜‰


ğŸ’¡So why not using this challenge to re-learn everything I know about data?

In short, I don't come from a technical background, I started working in Finance, was frustrated spending hours in Excel and VBA, and told myself how to code. 

Jupyter Notebooks and Python saved my life ğŸ™

I became an entrepreneur and ended up building an all-in-one data platform based on notebooks â†’ www.naas.ai 

With my team and a group of awesome contributors, we have open sourced more than +100 notebooks templates over the past 11 months


ğŸ‘‰ I have the feeling that this challenge is the best way to put my head into it again, re-learn how they work, and share this with you. 

Follow me JÃ©rÃ©my Ravenel if you want to stay updated. 

It's going to be about : 
#jupyternotebook 
#businessapplications  
#datamining #dataanalytics #datascience 
#automation
#ai
#lowcodeplatform

and I really hope you will benefit from the content I will share. 

For this first day, I am planning to watch the 19 videos playlist from Data Professor instead of Netflix ğŸ˜…

Stay tuned âœŒï¸

TEXT:

(1) Code is a highly sensitive decision-making process, it is power!

(2) Coder: someone whoÂ writes languageÂ for computers (aka machines)

(3) The first person to recognize that the machine had applications beyond pure calculation is a woman: Ada Byron

(4) The power of code amplifies the ability of people to do what they choose to do ğŸ§

(5) The history of code has been all about writing less than 1's and 0's: more power with less effort ğŸ™ƒ

(6) It's not complicated to get started with coding, build your own website (I did it in 5min with naas.ai) and learn how to ask questions to Google.

(7) ğŸŒ GUIs have enabled millions of people to use computers.

(8) "Transformer models, the next generation of AI, is totally changing the game because of their emerging nature: it can perform tasks it was not initially designed to do".  ğŸ™ Denis Rothman

â†’ They are getting implemented in every big tech company and we don't even see it (ex: Google search powered by Google BERT)

(9) Even if GPT3 is private, it's possible to train a Transformer model with decent hardware...and it's encouraging: "AI can be democratized" (anyone could train his own Transformer) ğŸ™ Thom Ives, Ph.D.

(10) Most of the coders are white and asian males programming today, leading to bias in AI â†’ We need more diversity! ğŸ’šğŸŒ

TITLE: âš¡ï¸ğŸ†“ How many people posting about data - automation - AI on LinkedIn do you follow?
TEXT:
âš¡ï¸ğŸ†“ How many people posting about data - automation - AI on LinkedIn do you follow?

Check out our Free LinkedIn Data Content Creators database to figure it out.


Last week, I shared 10 profiles to follow, but I realized that there are more than 80+ people creating content regularly on these subjects.Â 

Besides helping you stay informed on the current market trends, the content you read is here to inspire, educate, entertain or debate on problems you might face at work.

ğŸ¤ª I guess it makes you feel less alone.Â 
At least, this is what it is doing to me.

If it does not, maybe you are missing out on some amazing content.

This is why with Maxime (naas.ai CTO) we choose to apply our data skills to this topic.Â 

We created the first free â€œLinkedIn Data Content Creators databaseâ€, where you will be able to access a curated list of amazing people working in the data space. ğŸš€

Want to know how we did?Â 




...No surprise: we used www.naas.aiÂ 

Here is how we designed our notebook:
ğŸ‘‡

Input :
â†’ Get a handpicked list of content creators (name, profile URL) in Notion

Model :
â†’ Use LinkedIn Naas drivers to pull data (profile, posts).
â†’ Use DuckDB to store the data in parquet files by content creators with their profile and posts data.
â†’ Make aggregations and count the number of posts, likes, comments.
â†’ Calculate engagement score = (likes + comments) / followers *100

Output:
â†’ Use Naas and Notion drivers to populate a Notion database.

And you know the best part?Â 

A Naas engine is on a schedule to keep the list updated every Monday.



Do you find this interesting? 

ğŸ‘ğŸ’¬ Please feel free to share your thoughts in comments and tag amazing people that are not on this list ğŸ¤“



PS: if this post gets 1000 likes, we will take time to work on it more and integrate feedback + apply probably some ML in the process :)

TITLE: 99.5% of the world is illiterate...can you believe it?
TEXT:
99.5% of the world is illiterate...can you believe it?


They don't know how to code.

0.5% of the world's population knows how to code, which means 99.5% don't know how to build websites and mobile apps..and I'm not even talking about data products.

Literacy on digital tools is a big deal.

Apparently, 18.5 million is the number of real "developers" or "programmers" according to a study from IDC.
I don't know how many women, neither how diverse it is.

But, it's like the population of New York City-Newark Region, having super-powers comparing to the rest of the world.ğŸŒğŸ‘‘

Good news!
With the new generation of AI (NLP Transformer models), you can generate code by typing a simple sentence, soon it's going to be your voice.

Yet, if you don't know what or how to ask â†’ You will not get what you want.
ğŸ’© Garbage in, garbage out.

You need to understand the basics of coding to be able to talk to the machines.

TITLE: âœŠâš¡ï¸Pushing notebooks to production should NOT be so hard!
TEXT:
âœŠâš¡ï¸Pushing notebooks to production should NOT be so hard! 

When you work on Excel, everything you do is by default to production.

You update your spreadsheet, you share it with your audience. 
That's it. 


â†’ But when you start working on data science projects, replacing "Excel + VBA" by "Jupyter Notebooks + Python" 

You NEED TO DO A LOT to push to production, and it can be quite complicated to:

ğŸ›‘ convert your notebook to a python script 
ğŸ›‘ deploy it to on a server 
ğŸ›‘ set up a cron task to schedule it 
ğŸ›‘ ensure security
ğŸ›‘ make sure the whole ecosystem works together 

...when you actually want to focus on solving a business problem!


â†’ What if, instead, you could do that from your notebooks? 

With Naas notebooks, you can do that with minimum technical skills. 

You only need to master those 5 low code features: 

(1) â° Scheduler 
(2) ğŸ›ï¸ Notification 
(3) ğŸ–¼ï¸ Asset 
(4) âš™ï¸ Webhook 
(5) ğŸ”— Dependency 


â†’ What are the benefits? 

Imagine you need to produce an analysis of Tesla's (TSLA) stock price, use ML to predict +20days lines, and deliver it by email every day automatically. 

âœ… naas.scheduler.add(): run your notebook every day. â°

âœ… naas.notification.send(): email the result (copy your users), add attachments if needed. ğŸ›ï¸

âœ… naas.asset.add(): share static and dynamic graphs ğŸ–¼ï¸:

âœ… naas.webhook.add: re-run the notebook by clicking on a link. âš™ï¸

âœ… naas.dependency.add: isolate the content of your email from your code, so your users can modify the output easily ğŸ”—

This is only one example. 

With Naas, you CAN DO A LOT, without headaches. 



ğŸ‘‰ I created a template in the awesome-notebooks repository + a video (link in comment) to illustrate this. 

Just click on "Open in Naas" button to open the notebook (if you don't have an account, it creates one for you, and it's 100% free)
â†“ 
Input your email
â†“ 
Run the notebook. 

It will copy the notebook in naas "âš¡ â†’ Production" folder to be executed daily. 

â†“ 
Do you find this useful? ... 

ğŸ™ Thanks a lot for the support. 
ğŸ’¬ Comments are welcome, tell me what kind of use case you want to see next. 


PS: we're working hard to build Naas, and need more help! If you know anybody who would like to contribute to open source, please let us know and tell your friends! 

PSS: follow naas.ai and join our Slack community for more open source magic (link in comment)ğŸ’š

TITLE: ğŸŒğŸš€ Africa is on the rise, ready to be part of the next wave of AI innovation!
TEXT:
ğŸŒğŸš€ Africa is on the rise, ready to be part of the next wave of AI innovation!


This weekend, I was invited by Zion Pibowei to give a talk to a group of #datageeks ğŸ¤™ from different African countries.


I really wanted to connect with all those minds, and what I learned was amazing. 


â†’ Like me, most of them got interested in data, automation, and AI, because they faced real-world problems they want to fix. âš¡ï¸

â†’ They totally get what we are trying to do at naas.ai: making Jupyter notebooks production-ready to bridge the gap between tech and business teams ğŸ™

â†’ Ethical AI issues and explainability of the models are at the center of their preoccupation. 

They want to take a stand and correct the biases we currently face with this technology. 

(yes, most of the people coding AI models are male, white, caucasian or asian...and this is a problem! ğŸš¨)

â†’ They understand that the power of AI is in making it available to the masses; and that NLP transformers models can help us get there.

â†’ Most of them want to get involved in projects, but only a few have started looking at Open Source!  

âœ… So, I showed them how simple it was to become a contributor to Naas Open Source project with the awesome-notebooks. ğŸŒ±


As the world moves deeper into the Fourth Industrial Revolution, what is next for Africa in HUGE!

The continentâ€™s entrepreneurs are taking advantage of this growth in connectivity to create tech hubsÂ across the continent. 

This is fueling innovation...

and I don't see any reason why Africa can't have AI companies building AI solutions that serve the rest of the world.ğŸŒğŸ¦„

TITLE: âœ‹ğŸ›‘ Stop writing messy code in notebooks, embrace jupyter-naas templates!
TEXT:
âœ‹ğŸ›‘ Stop writing messy code in notebooks, embrace jupyter-naas templates!


Jupyter notebooks are awesome. 

You can write text and run code in the same document. 

It enables fast prototyping, debugging, and effective storytelling for your data projects. 

And, it provides a place for business and tech people to be literally on the same page!

Nonetheless, notebooks come with their own limitations, the most annoying ones being:

ğŸ›‘ limited scalability,Â 
ğŸ›‘ tendency to push developers to duplicate code,
ğŸ›‘ lack of a standard structure.

Lots of articles, posts, and talks are talking about it: 

Joel Grus, inÂ "I donâ€™t like notebooks" ğŸ¤®, accuses notebooks of creating bad habits in developers and data scientists.

William Koehrsen suggests blaming sins ğŸ˜ˆ and not sinners ğŸ˜¨ and proposes an interesting solution:

â†’ Creating a template. 
A standard yet flexible skeleton for every kind of Data Science notebook.

We came to the same conclusion as William with naas.ai awesome-notebooks templates ğŸš€

â†’ So we developed a template framework : 

Each notebook should be structured using markdown (text) with:

'''
# Tool - Action verb explaining the target
Description: Â a quick summary of what the notebook does
Author: First Name, Last Name linked to a social profile
Tags: any relevant hashtag

## Input 
Import libraries
Add variables 
Data import 

## Model 
All the functions, a list of transformations applied to the input.

## Output 
Any kind of asset (data frame, graph, excel...) that needs to be consumed by the end-user.
 
ğŸ‘ What are the benefits? 

âœ… With a common skeleton, anyone can understand what's going on, and share it. Even non-tech people â­ï¸
âœ… The description allows the reader to decide whether to dive deep into the code or just run the notebook 
âœ… With sections already there, you save time formatting and can focus on how to document.
âœ… Refactoring relevant code and integrating it into a module or library (like naas_drivers) become easy

TITLE: ğŸŒğŸ‘ ğŸ‘ Is an "idea" environmentally friendly?

Today, let's ask a T5 AI transformer model to answer âœ… Good or âŒ Bad to a few statements. Keep reading ğŸ˜‰ğŸ‘‡

T5, or Text-to-Text Transfer Transformer, is an extremely large neural network model (11 billion parameters) thatÂ can perform any kind of natural language processing (NLP) task.

In our example, we used the Hugging Face API to get access to the T5 model.

The results were quite interesting...

TITLE: If you want to apply your coding skills to solve a business problem. â†’ Don't think too much about the technical stuff ğŸ¤¯âš™ï¸
TEXT:
If you want to apply your coding skills to solve a business problem. â†’ Don't think too much about the technical stuff ğŸ¤¯âš™ï¸

Instead, think about the word "TRIBE". ğŸ™ğŸ¤—

Yes. Like a TRIBE. 
A tribe isÂ a group of people that share ancestry and cultures while living in their own enclosed society.

It may seem counter-intuitive at first. 

But I can assure you that you are on the same tribe as those end-users you want to serve. 

You may not speak the same language. 
They don't know how to speak to machines, you do. 

But you fall under the same umbrella: human beings. 

ğŸš¨ And the key for your project to be successful is adoption by those humans beings!


T.R.I.B.E is a brilliant framework that has been developed by Mark Freeman II to get from ideas to production in the smartest fashion. 


ğŸ¥‡ It is, to date, the best framework I encountered to bridge the gap between technical and business people.


Here is what it means. ğŸ‘‡

T â†’ Talk to your stakeholders to determine their needs and pain points.

R â†’ Build out your requirements at a high level by creating a brief analysis plan, data tables, and sketch out the MVP (Minimum Viable Product) output. It might be a report, an app, an email...

I â†’ Iterate by going back to your stakeholders with your requirements to get feedback. Your MVPs, sketches, and plans move the project from abstract to tangible allowing your stakeholders to give you much better requirements.

B â†’ Build your project to the best version possible with the time constraint given by your stakeholders.

E â†’ Evangelize your project by being strategic on how to communicate the value proposition. Be bold, be broad, and encourage buy-in and long-term adoption. 

Also, by collaborating with stakeholders early (T and I) you are already starting the evangelize process and your collaboration with them creates ownership!



Here is a Livestream I made with Mark Freeman II where he talks about his experience as a data scientist working at Humu. 

He is also sharing how his thoughts process on a notebook analyzing his LinkedIn data. 

Watch the replay if you have time. 
It's full of very insightful tips and tricks. 

+ Mark is awesome ğŸ˜‰ğŸ’š. He is currently working on very cool open source contributions on naas.ai

Stay tuned.

TITLE: âš¡ï¸ğŸ‘¿ Why do most business people don't understand what the hell "pushing to production" mean?
TEXT:
âš¡ï¸ğŸ‘¿ Why do most business people don't understand what the hell "pushing to production" mean?

This is the story about a "fight" between Business and IT departments ğŸ¥Š

When I started as a financial analyst, I never understood why any technical requirements involving the IT department was :
â†’ looking way more complicated than it seemed
â†’ taking way too long to be executed
â†’ never respected the deadline.

We mostly asked them to automate basic models running on Excel, like:
â†’ Extracting data from applications
â†’ Cleaning and merging datasets together
â†’ Creating an Excel spreadsheet with pivot tables and graphs
â†’ Sending it to our boss on a daily basis

Nothing fancy right? 
Yet, most of our queries ended up nowhere.

ğŸ¤¯ The IT department was answering this with a "Pro-forma Business Requirement Document",
that needed to be filled ASAP,
to end up in their backlog...
...and delivered
NEVER.

Why? Because:
(1) by the time we were done filling it, our needs would have changed!
(2) IT priorities were elsewhere, they were dealing with infrastructure, pushing major evolutions to Production.

Production?
Yes.
When you work with applications, you develop and test changes. You commit code to a repository to ensure version control (VC).
There, a continuous integration (CI) system can take this code and build it, to expose it on a server, used by the quality assurance (QA) team to do further tests, and eventually gives its green light to â€œpush the code to productionâ€!

= face the real world, the users.

Don't get me wrong, those processes are important.
But the problem is, most of the time they cannot follow the speed of business requirements that are changing very fast.

ğŸš¨ This is why we created naas.ai
And in this new update, we chose to expose the "âš¡ï¸â†’Production" folder used to schedule, expose, trigger actions inside Notebooks.

If you are an analyst, you can use it to automate all the boring stuff.
If you are a data scientist/software developer, you can use it to prototype and deliver to the business faster, and more...

TITLE: ğŸ§ "Whatâ€™s the difference between Software Engineer and Data Scientist?"
TEXT:
ğŸ§ "Whatâ€™s the difference between Software Engineer and Data Scientist?"

This is the question I asked today to GPT-3. Keep reading ğŸ˜‰ğŸ‘‡

It all started with a conversation with Axel, a contributor to naas.ai open source project. 

He wanted to know whether he should define himself as a Software Engineer or Data Scientist. 
...I tried to help him define the 2 to the best of my ability.

But the truth is...lines are getting blurry. 

With the new generation of AI (ie: the transformers models like #BERT or #GPT3), users may be able to develop their own AI applications.

ğŸš¨Does it mean that technical roles are out of the game? 
I don't think so, but I wanted to ask the AI itself using my GPT3 API access. 

ğŸ‘‰ Here are the results when I used a simple "Q&A" task:

Q: Whatâ€™s the difference between Software Engineer and Data Scientist? 
A: Software Engineers build software. Data Scientists build models.

Q: Will Data Scientists and Software Engineers will be replaced by Transformer models? 
A: No. 

Q: Why? 
A: Because Data Scientists and Software Engineers are not Transformer models.

ğŸ‘‰ Then I designed a curated input from different Google search responses, and used the "Summarize for 2nd grader" task:

The first answer with limited words (called tokens) 

```
Software engineering is about creating the tools that let people create things, like video games. Data science is about using those tools to make the games better, like by making them run faster. Both are important!
```

The second answer with 300 words.

```
Software Engineering is a field of computer science that focuses on the development of computer applications and the features of computers.Â 

Data Science is a field of computer science that focuses on gathering, processing, analyzing, and extracting insights from data.Â 

Software engineers develop the programs that data scientists use to gather and process data. 

Data scientists analyze the data gathered by software engineers. Software engineers create programs that capture data and store it for data scientists to analyze. 

Data scientists analyze the data stored by software engineers.
```


âš¡ï¸ How amazing is that? âš¡ï¸
â†’ Do you find the results accurate?
Please share your views in comments ğŸ‘ğŸ’¬


PS: Denis, thanks for your training and posts on the subject. I here try to share my humble understanding. 
I am slowly getting it ğŸ˜…
